  Facebook 's tax affairs have been criticised, following a Sunday Times report which suggested it had paid $2.9m (£1.85m) in tax last year, despite generating $3.5bn earnings.
  The social network routed the majority of its overseas profits through an Irish subsidiary, which then redirected to a company in the British tax haven of Cayman Islands.
  This meant Facebook Ireland only reported a £15.1m loss in 2011, less than 0.2 per cent of the £448.2m it shifted to the Cayman unit.

## What do we mean by "Cardinal"?

Cardinal is an official ecclesiastical title for certain members of the Roman Catholic (RCC) clergy. In English, the word cardinal takes its origin from the Latin adjective cardinalis (source and see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardinal_(Roman_Catholic_Church)) and has a meaning close to 'essential' or 'fundamental' or even 'indispensible'; the name of the bird comes from the same source.

In the RCC the cardinal is an important person, a Pope's helper who represents the Catholic Church within the world, so as to give support and advice to the Pope in his role of being the leader of the Church, and who elect the new Popes in the conclave.

  ## How good is AI at writing these?

  The AI has to be at least as good as a human, if not better.

  And how useful would it be in journalistic terms? It could perhaps be used for summaries, as mentioned in other replies.

  It's unlikely to replace journalists, and it would depend on the topic and the specific style of writing.

  In some cases, AI can be surprisingly good at generating text that is highly similar to human writing.

  However, it would always be a good idea to double check the information before using it.

  ## ChatGPT is a language model developed by OpenAI.

  It was designed to generate human-like text in natural language.

  It can be used to generate text in a wide variety of topics, including articles, stories, answers to questions, descriptions, poems, jokes, etc.

"opportunities" would arise from Brexit and emphasised the UK's "shared ambitions and above all shared values".

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said the Easter message of peace "could not have more urgency throughout the world".

Mrs May, who is a vicar's daughter, said that shared values "can and must bring us together" following the UK's vote to leave the EU by 52% to 48% in June 2016.

Disability is a concept we all struggle with. It affects all aspects of society, from our understanding of ourselves as being abled or not abled people, to the way society itself functions. This is not only about understanding our rights as disabled people, but also about understanding our responsibilities to the rights of others. Disability is a complex issue, and there are many ways for disabled people to be treated differently in society. Whether it's in the workplace, in school, when using public transport, or while interacting with the government, disability is a social challenge for all of us. This is also true when it comes to the workplace. It's not uncommon for employers to make assumptions about disabled people and what they can and cannot do, or, worse, to exclude them altogether. There are many ways the workplace can be inclusive, however, and there are also strategies we can use to make our employers more aware of the challenges we face. The following suggestions are by no means exhaustive, but they are a good starting point for understanding how you can be more inclusive and how to avoid assumptions about your disability and what you can or cannot do. * Get to know the culture of your workplace, and the people who work there. The body of a 17-year-old girl who went missing after swimming between Barry and Cardiff Bay has been found, police say.Police believe she was attempting to swim across to Cardiff Bay when the alarm was raised at about 21:55 BST.
South Wales Fire and Rescue tweeted she had got in trouble in the middle of the bay and was treading water to stay safe.Police said they believed the teenager had died in the open water and they were called off after the search at around 22:30.
Earlier, the fire service tweeted: 'She's been found by our boat. Lifeboat and coastguard now attending as well as ambulance.'
The girl was rescued by a fire service boat and treated by paramedics, a spokeswoman for South Wales Fire and Rescue Service tweeted.
The spokeswoman said fire crews were called to Barry Harbour at about 22:40 amid reports the teenager was struggling in the water.
Earlier a member of the public had seen the teenager struggling in the bay. The girl was first helped by people in a passing vessel and then rescued by the fire boat

Players with a prescription for medicine, but only the medicines listed as banned by the World Anti-Doping Agency will be penalised.
The ESL was formed in Germany in 2000 but many of its events take place in eastern Europe.
In July, the ESL said it would launch an anti-doping programme after a top gamer admitted taking a performance-enhancing drug.
Restrictions apply "from the start of the first day until the end of the last day of competition", but players will not be punished for drugs taken outside of a competition.

In an email to alumni and Vassar College staff and faculty members, Interim President Catharine Hill explains that "in November 2016, the College received reports of several acts of racist graffiti, some of which included language of a sexually explicit nature and some of which were directed against the LGBTQ+ community (one form of hate speech is when racist, transphobic and other slurs are used to attack individuals.)" Council waste enforcement officers went to Ithon Grove, Kings Norton, after reports that six fridges had been dumped on Tuesday.
But on arrival they were stunned to find dozens of the appliances strewn along the road.
Dozens of fridges and other electrical items were found dumped on the side of Kings Norton's Ithon Grove,
  Birmingham City Council said the illegal dumping was "totally unacceptable" and said staff were tried to identify the perpetrators.

The spokesman for the authority said: "It's outrageous that people think dumping rubbish on a road, blighting our city, is acceptable. "This is totally unacceptable and we will prosecute fly-tippers where evidence is available."

Alan Bullard, environmental services manager for Birmingham City Council, said it was a ''scandalous' picture of Ithon Grove in Kings Norton, which was 'worse than an episode of a fly tipper's paradise' TV show.

He told ITV News Central that there is 'simply no excuse' for the 'environmental crime' and that the council would not let it happen.

He said: "The vast majority of people work incredibly hard and do exactly the right thing and the vast majority of people are angry and angry at the fact that this very small minority of people cause havoc to the environment and spoil it for the vast majority of people.

(CNN) -- Nokia and Microsoft announced plans to bring a pair of Windows Phone smartphones to market next month.
The devices will be among the first batch of Windows Phones to be announced after the two companies announced plans in early February to develop the devices together. The phones were officially announced Wednesday at Nokia World, an event in London for Nokia partners and developers.
The phones on tap are the Nokia 800 and 900, respectively. Microsoft is contributing the software that runs the devices, including the company's flagship Bing search engine, while Nokia contributes the hardware and the phones' physical design.
There are four main models of Windows Phone 7 available now: Tilt 2 for Sprint; a second Tilt 2, this time for AT&T, Dell's Venue Pro and the HTC Surround for AT&T. Microsoft is expected to unveil new devices at the beginning of October at a press conference.

  A splinter group of the Pakistani Taliban said it carried out the attack.

`In the last two weeks the country has seen what may be the most serious and sustained round of civil turmoil since the uprisings of the 60s. With a single act of police violence a young man was killed sparking intense emotions across the US. It's not just the killing but what is seen as a clear double standard in the US justice system which makes people feel a grievance and act on it. The riots may be small in terms of the areas that have been affected and the number of people engaged but they have highlighted the extent and level of dissatisfaction in a number of cities, they have been a catalyst for a wider outpouring of emotion and they have revealed the extent of disaffection amongst blacks and other minority races. While not unexpected from a viewpoint of history repeating itself it will be interesting to see how this plays out in the next few years.

This team has shown how they can use a computer with complex analysis software to search for the genetic mutations in a single leukemia cancer cell. Once they were found the same analysis will find how these mutations are different. They did this analysis in about 180 samples of leukemia cells and found that the mutations were different than even in a single cell. They did this analysis in 5 children with leukemia.
This will have wide implications for how we use chemotherapy in children with leukaemia. A single dose of chemotherapy kills most of the cells in a tumour, but there is always a small percentage of tumour cells left over that may not have been killed or are too far from the chemotherapy. They are also the most probable source of mutations that allow the leukemia to grow back and resist future treatments. If these last few cells are found and killed the cancer might be gone forever.
Since these studies in children we can take the same type of look at colon and pancreatic cancer. We are doing this by getting a biopsy from a colon mass and a piece of normal tissue. We are cutting the biopsy to as small as possible and

Leukaemias come in many different forms. We tested one form in particular, acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL), which affects about 150 children each year in the UK
  Although ALL is the most common type of leukaemia in children, it is actually made up of many subtypes. ALL is difficult to cure, and patients often relapse after seemingly successful treatment. One of the reasons why this type of leukaemia is resistant to treatment is that when a single leukaemia cell develops, it starts to mutate, so that a whole new population of leukaemia cells springs up. Because leukaemia cells are constantly under strong selection pressure, the leukaemia cells will rapidly diverge in a process called clonal evolution and will not respond well to therapies that are targeted to particular versions of the disease.
  To understand this process, we have compared the genes of leukaemia cells from five patients to see whether the patterns of mutation they had in common indicated an initial "trunk" from which the disease diverged.
  What we found was extraordinarily diverse. We

This work shows the importance of heterogeneity in the context of treatment - we need to consider individual patient characteristics when deciding a course of treatment.

Amber Rudd, the Home Secretary, told the BBC the British government was considering forcing EU citizens to obtain permits to work in Britain following Brexit. Speaking on Sunday’s Andrew Marr programme, she said it was possible to move away from the free movement of people without losing access to the single market, but that “the details will have to be worked out”. It is “a given” that people voted Leave to limit immigration, she acknowledged. The government had “complete control” over the numbers of migrants entering the country in future, with some “provisos” including a “reciprocal exchange” where Britain’s access to the European Union is dependent on the free movement of people. The Conservatives’ long-term target was to reduce net migration to tens of thousands, she said. It would “take some time” to achieve that but “yes, tens of thousands”. She also confirmed the government was “looking at ways of reducing numbers in student visas”. However, that did not mean imposing a blanket ban. The home secretary’s comments came as Mrs May attempted to calm tensions within the Conservative Party and her Cabinet over her Brexit strategy. A week after the snap election, which saw the Conserv

`` 1. Article: Amber Rudd told the BBC the work permit proposal "certainly has value" but nothing was being ruled out. She accepted EU nations could choose to impose new restrictions, including requiring Britons to apply for permission before travelling. Ms Rudd said it was a "given" people voted Leave to reduce immigration. Speaking on the Andrew Marr Show, she reiterated the prime minister's dismissal of a points-based system to control EU migration championed by Brexit campaigners in the build-up to the referendum, saying it "simply doesn't work". Few of our actions in the global war on terrorism are as fraught with controversy, or as sensitive, as the employment of armed drones. Our government uses armed drones frequently, and often with deadly efficiency. Few other actions in the war on terrorism, and the war in Afghanistan, are as sensitive as targeted killings. If this is a war with conventional rules, and the drones represent one leg of the triad of special ops, surveillance, and drones that is now engaged to end this war as quickly as possible (and without the cost, in terms of lives, that previous US armed forces operations incurred), then our society does in fact have a serious stake in understanding the rules. And not just the legal, or ethical, or moral rules, but also the strategic rules. When President Obama took over as commander in chief, he promised to use drones sparingly. That hasn't happened, and while there is an important debate going on about whether our government should be spending this much money on a new kind of warfare, there are many more questions we should be asking. ```

The Indian government is overhauling some prison laws and practices, officials announced. Jail authorities must now let death row convicts see their families before execution, part of a set of prison reforms announced by the government to modernise the country's notorious prisons. Legal aid centres will be set up in all jails, and better health care will also be provided, the new rules say. There are more than 400,000 inmates in prisons across India, with more than half of them awaiting trial.```

```1.  India says it will allow family visits for death row prisoners

17 January 2016
From the section Asia
India's Home Minister Rajnath Singh
India will for the first time allow family visits for death row prisoners, officials say.
Cases of violence against prisoners, including against women, are rising, Human Rights Commission Chairperson Justice HL Dattu said on Thursday.
Mr Singh, who was chairing a two-day meeting to deliberate on reforms in the prisons, said jail officials have been asked to ensure the safety of female and weaker prisoners. The new guidelines come after several instances last year, including reports in northern Haryana state of women being subjected to sexual violence and of women dying in custody.

Prisoners in India - especially the poorer ones - will be given more access to family and legal support, the Ministry of Home Affairs announced today.
Last year alone, there were 400,000 inmates in the country.
Inmates will also be provided with better health care.
However, the plans have no mention of the controversial death penalty.

Article: Commissioner Nóirín O'Sullivan denied a decision to refer the matter to GSOC was meant to keep it from the public.
It follows the revelation that large sums of EU funding were put in a bank account in a former officer's name.
The parliamentary Public Accounts Committee (PAC) has also been investigating the allegations.
For several months, the PAC has been investigating how accounts at the training college in Templemore, County Tipperary, including one designed to cover laundry bills, were used for other purposes including paying restaurant and entertainment bills.
Commissioner O'Sullivan has, in the past, described what happened at Templemore and the evidence of poor financial controls there as a legacy issue.
The money involved in the GSOC investigation came from an EU-funded training programme, and the commissioner told the PAC the account predates her time and that of her predecessor as commissioner, Martin Callinan.
She said the account operated from Dublin over an 11-year period, from 1999 until it was closed in 2010.
She said her understanding was that this was a police

* There are problems in how accounts at a Garda training college are being handled, and this has been known for several months.
  * A Garda commissioner has admitted that €85,469 was wrongly paid into a bank account set up by her predecessor.
  * The commissioner said she was "gobsmacked" at the "level of detail" in the accounts that came to light in recent weeks, which included €5,400 being spent on a 28-seat private jet to take members of the force to France.

At first glance, the statement might seem innocent enough -- perhaps even cute. But it’s a sharp rebuke to thousands of Hong Kongers who staged a massive protest just three months ago in an unsuccessful call for Leung’s resignation. `The Irish artists Clear Connolly have spent years developing a series of aluminum helmets that explore ‘the mysteries of visual perception.’ Here, an individual tries on the horse helmet, which puts their eyes on the sides so that they can experience the 357-degree view as if they were a horse. Anne Cleary and Denis Connolly were inspired to make the helmets after exploring the pioneering experiments of psychologist George Malcolm Stratton in the early twentieth century. They wore special glasses that inverted images up and down and left and right for more than a week and discovered that the human brain could adapt to newly altered perceptions with practice.```` The link to the paper : `https://arxiv.org/abs/1710.04620`

The helmet is a piece of scientific research that seeks to change your point of view, literally. The idea is that it changes the way we view a horse's race, inverting the images so it's as though we were stood sideways. The idea of changing the way we perceive a race is the inspiration for this project. The first horse helmet was made by Irish artists, Denis Connolly and Anne Cleary in 2006. They took the idea and developed it into a new piece of art for the National Art Gallery in Ireland in 2009, and it has since been shown at the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich and the National Museum of Ireland. Their research led them to discover that horse racing is actually really hard to see, which is why there are so many accidents - the inability to see what's going on around you and how fast you are moving. So now, using the helmet, the Irish artists have found that we have changed the way we perceive a race, the way we see the speed, the race itself, the other competitors and the crowd. But what about the race itself? Well, the horses don't notice a difference at all. That hasn't stopped

A series of strange but fascinating aluminium helmets, which let you experience the world from a different perspective, have been created by two artists in Ireland. The helmets were inspired by the work of psychologist George Melcolm Stratton who experimented with glasses that inverted the world upside down and switched left for right. The helmets first went on display at the National Museum of Ireland in November and are now at the Centre Culturel Irlandais in Paris. The helmets, by Irish artists Denis Connolly and Anne Cleary, use optical tricks to put you in the eye of a cheetah for six seconds or enable someone with a brain injury to see in four different directions (images of four helmets are illustrated). The artists created them to enable people to appreciate their visual perception. An illustration of one of the helmets is shown, and a horse seen through one is placed above it alongside an image of a horse and mane in a barn. Helmets which let you see the world through different animal eyes, including those of a chameleon, have been created by two artists in Ireland. Vitamin D supplements show little evidence to support a health claim.  Vitamin D is taken by millions of people worldwide to protect against a wide range of diseases, for example cancer, heart disease and stroke, but a new study led by the International   Prevention   Research Institute published in The Lancet has shown   they have   little effect, at least for older people.   The   results reveal a lack of evidence that supplements containing vitamin   D protect against more than 17 diseases, for example cancer, heart disease, stroke, Alzheimer’s Disease, Parkinson’s disease,    multiple sclerosis and rheumatoid arthritis. The   researchers, led by Philippe Autier from the International Prevention Research Institute, have carried out a meta-analysis of 462 studies involving more than a million adults using vitamin D supplementation during a minimum follow-up of one year. In the 1950s and ’60s, with smoking and drunkenness on the rise, firefighters became concerned that public facilities were not being built to deal with the increasing need for fire safety. By the 1970s these fears had not been allayed. Fire exits were poorly signed and the fire-resistant materials of the 30s and ’40s had fallen into disrepair.

Around 1975, a 97-year-old woman was killed when her house caught fire, and the fire service had to fight the blaze with the help of three brigades, a special appliance, and water carts; one fireman had to make his way through the house with just a hosepipe. This was clearly the result of lack of investment [in fire safety]. In 1976 a committee was set up under the chairmanship of MP Sir John Burn, to look into the problem of fires in public buildings.

This week the National Police Chiefs' Council (NPCC) will launch the second phase of its week of action on distracted drivers. Police will be running an enforcement week from Monday 14 to Sunday 20 November, focused on educating the public and deterring motorists from picking up their mobile phones at the wheel. The operations will include dedicated patrols and messages on road signs, with officers running high-visibility and unmarked patrols on the most hazardous roads in their areas. There will be a continued focus on the education of the public - via video content and use of social media - to ensure motorists are well-informed of the dangers of using a phone behind the wheel. The week of action, which follows government plans to double fines and points for using a mobile while driving, aims to make 'driving distracted' as socially unacceptable as drink driving.``` Please don't use the "reply with quote" button. The Prime Minister has said the UK should make available another 20,000 places for Syrian refugees. He said some of those places would be filled with people from camps on the border of Syria rather than those already in Europe. Mr Cameron said he wanted to see more safe corridors created as a way of getting more help to people, saying there are more than 20 refugees or asylum seekers arriving in Europe per day. He said any refugee who arrived in Europe should get the same kind of treatment and protection "wherever they choose to start their journey in Europe". He added that the government was working with the French to find ways of tackling gangs helping people traffic themselves across the Eurotunnel, saying: "I am keen to work with the French government to see what more we can do to crack that, to cut off that route that people are using so dangerously and so illegally."

Britain will take in 1,000 migrants from refugee camps, Cameron says.
They will come from in or near countries affected by the war, rather than those already in Europe.
Aid organisations estimate 5 million refugees are displaced in Syria, Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey and 1.2million have arrived in Greece and Italy in the past six months.
Mr Cameron said the UK had always accepted asylum claims from Iraqi, Syrian, and Sudanese refugees and there was no reason to change that, though it might take time to put measures in place.
The PM said other countries should do more to help migrants in Europe and he has invited EU leaders to discuss the issue at a summit later this month.
The UNHCR has said it is facing its biggest global crisis since the 1940s.```

## UK: Migrants (27

We will provide practical assistance both in the camps at our borders and further afield to help those displaced. Our ambition is to help a million refugees in the region find security and opportunity, not come to Britain. This means helping to build a better future for people in neighbouring countries and tackling the threat that causes so much of this migration in the first place. This Government will fund a new £100m Refugee Support Strategy. The UK has so far contributed £730m to support the refugees, but we can do more. The strategy, run through the Department for International Development, will help displaced people in camps in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan, where millions are unable to get jobs or a decent education. That means better shelter, medical care, schools and support to rebuild their economies. It will help with the education of two million children and ensure three million have access to clean water and sanitation. That support for refugees is vital, because we are at the front line of a growing challenge that is overwhelming border controls in Europe. The numbers coming is putting huge pressure on the camps to the south of Europe where millions of people are struggling to survive and more migrants are arriving every day. The more people come

This week the UK Government has announced to give a little help to the Syrian refugees currently camped in the 4 southern provinces of Turkey on the Syrian border. The aim is to relieve the pressure caused by such large groups of people. The refugees will be given refugee status for one year and will get financial aid to move to the UK to get an asylum for humanitarian reasons. UK will receive 4,500 refugees from Turkey, with 2,500 of those coming in the first six months of the Syrian war. Other parties and refugee NGOs have expressed that the help is welcome but that is should be more. There are a lot of refugees in Turkey and the Turkish government is struggling to offer help with the Syrian refugee crisis. Many refugee families have fled their homes, taking only the belongings they can carry, leaving their homes and belongings behind. Turkey has responded by providing a significant level of humanitarian aid but this needs to be further supported. In addition, thousands more have made the long journey to Greece, seeking a safe place to continue their journey into Northern Europe.'' ```

The Mashco Piro tribe is an uncontacted tribe of indigenous Amazonian people living in the jungles of eastern Peru. They were first recorded by explorers in 1953 and have never formally allowed contact due to the fear of outside contamination and disease. They are part of an area in Peru protected by the government against foreign or settler intervention with the aim to "promote dialogue and mutual cooperation that allows the sustainable development of indigenous people" in the area. They have been observed but not contacted numerous times in the last decade. Most recently, a tribesman has come into contact with a group of villagers near a local river, but there is some dispute on what actually happened. The Peruvian government released a news release claiming that the man had been shot by the group with a Yawanawa arrow belonging to the local Yanomami tribe, an act of defense as they are known to be violent. However, locals say the Yanomami attacked a young member of the tribe, who in turn stabbed three of the members, leading to counterattack from the tribe. This is one of the few violent encounters between the Mashco Piro tribe and other residents in the area, and the

The man was shot with an arrow when members of the isolated Mashco Piro tribe invaded his village, Shipetiari, in the rainforest. It is the third time this year that the Mashco Piro people have been seen. Anthropologists say they were probably looking for tools or food. However, it is not known why the Mashco Piro attacked. The group is estimated to number around 600 and they live in separated  groups, constantly moving through the forest. They occasionally make makeshift shelters along river banks and dig for turtle eggs. Peru's government has forbidden physical contact with them and another dozen or so "uncontacted" indigenous tribes because they have little immunity or resistance to illnesses that other humans carry. Anthropologists say that in the area of jungle where they have been seen, near the Madre de Dios river in southern Peru, some locals have been trying to tempt the Mashco Piro out of the forest with rewards, pitying what is seen as a primitive existence. The Peruvian government has been financing a group of indigenous specialists for some time in the area to deal with contacts between settled communities

Democrats who have donated to a presidential campaign this election are more likely than Republicans to have done so on the Internet, according to a new study. Nearly 57% of Democrats who contributed to the campaigns have done so online, while only 34% of Republican donors used the Internet to make their contribution, found the Pew Internet & American Life Project. Conversely, 87% of Republican donors have given money in person, over the phone or through snail-mail, while 57% of Democratic donors have contributed offline (The numbers don't total 100% because people can make multiple donations in various ways). Neither side is more likely to donate in general: Pew found that 16% of both Democrats and Republicans have contributed to a campaign in some fashion. While offline donations are still the most popular form of contributions, the Internet's a close second: of the 13% of adults who contributed to a campaign, 67% did so in-person, on the phone or through traditional mail, while 50% donated online or via email. What about cell phone donations? Democratic donors are more

Democrats who made the personal choice to make a donation to a presidential   campaign, are more likely than Republicans to have donated online, according   to a new study.   Ninetyseven percent of Americans have not donated to any campaign, and among   the 3 percent who did, 71 percent made their donation offline, typically by   snail mail, in-person, or by phone. Forty-nine percent who contributed   online did so via their laptop computer, and another 8 percent did so via   smart phone.   Democrats are 2.7 times more likely than Republicans to have donated   via smart phone (P<.001) and more likely to have contributed to a   campaign by an other means such as text message or mobile app   (P<.05) ```

Bullied throughout school for having neurological disorders and not having a father, 10-year-old Tyrone Taylor, found his escape through guitar.  At the age of 12, Tyrone was given a hand-me-down guitar and a chord book; from there he taught himself how to play basic songs.  Through practicing and playing his guitar, he eventually found a passion for it.  From there, he found peace and happiness while playing music even after school, which led him to become a musician and eventually, a teacher to others. ```

```

I believe it was December of '98 when my dad passed away of an overdose. A few weeks later, around my 10th birthday, I was diagnosed with Tourette syndrome and Asperger's syndrome. It was a really rough time, especially at that age, being told I have a neurological "disease," when I already felt so different. At that point I was being bullied for being different, having big ears, and now for having no dad AND for making weird faces and noises I couldn't control. I was a walking target. Then my mom discovered a musical interest in me after my older sister was in musical theater at her high school. I learned all the songs from the show "Damn Yankees" and at the final performance, the director let me go onstage (my first time onstage) and perform with the cast! I was hooked instantly and for some reason it felt right. Although I felt I had found "my place," I still had to go back to my own school. The bullying just kept getting worse. I didn't know what to do anymore. I even had thoughts of suicide and hurting myself.

The Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi resigned from his post after the Sunday referendum on the proposed constitutional reforms. He asked President Sergio Mattarella to allow another six weeks for passing the budget bill. President Mattarella agreed to the request for time on practical grounds. Mr Renzi’s centre-left Democratic Party had pledged to hold general elections within six months. However, the anti-establishment parties such as the Five Star Movement have called for early parliamentary elections even though it is difficult to implement them within six months. Prime Minister Renzi campaigned extensively to pass the referendum. The approval would have streamlined the Senate, Italy’s second house of parliament, which has a limited role. It would also have made it easier for the government to pass reforms. However, the vote has ended his premiership and he is likely to be succeeded by a care taker government. He had previously said that he would resign if the referendum failed```

The pair already filed a complaint last year with the Illinois Department of Human Rights against the taxi company and the driver, Jama Anshur. Anshur was fined $1,540 by the Chicago Department of Business Affairs and Consumer Protection and was also fired over the incident, which took place on May 30 2013. Mr McCrea and Mr White had flown from L.A. to Chicago O’Hare International Airport and were heading back to Mr McCrea’s apartment when they jumped into the taxi. After sharing what they say was a short kiss, Anshur became adamant they exit the cab, claiming 'you can't do this -this is public transportation'. We report on the new analysis of PUMA SRTM DEM by TANDEM-X satellite. After careful examination we could identify two types of error. TANDEM-X could not detect features with height below threshold of 0.5 meters above the mean sea level. The other type of error is caused by the so-called “double pass effect”, which is not possible to eliminate completely - because SRTM orbit direction is not always the same, we can obtain different results from the same area which may add together to result in doubled DEM. These errors are caused by different factors, but they can both result in high noise level in the SRTM/TANDEM-X DEM. This means that no accurate analysis of this DEM can be done unless the errors are reduced or eliminated. ```

The police can use 'The Proceeds of Crime Act' to seize money which has been found in the possession of a person that they 'have a reasonable suspicion' was obtained as a result of a criminal act, even if the person who possesses the money has not themselves committed said criminal act, and regardless of whether or not they possess evidence that the person commited a criminal act, or evidence that the person was merely in receipt of the money as a result of the criminal act. The Act seems designed to enable police to 'take a cut' of the proceeds of crime, rather than to enable the police force to take criminals to court, and is probably being misused to do so. This was one of the cases where Leon Quarless was apparently being taken to court, but the law as it stands was being used by the police to take the £4,972 of his money that he had on him, and to put it in the police stations general bank account. ``` The same sort of thing can be done by taxation authorities, such as the HMRC (Her Majesty's Revenue & Customs) by the authorities having the power to 'assume that all of this mans wealth is a

Kate Matrosova, 32, dropped off by her husband Charlie Farhoodi at the base of New Hampshire's 5,400ft Mount Madison at 5am last Sunday. The UK does not even rank among the top 10 countries for producing billionaire entrepreneurs. Although it has a higher number than countries in the Eurozone it still lags behind the likes of Hong Kong, the USA, Australia, Canada and Ireland.

The purpose of this article is to show how UK ranks is low the number of entrepreneurs with the wealth above $1 billion. Also to show the comparison with the rest of the countries, which are more successful.

(China) Beijing airport, Saturday: Members of Moranbong band unexpectedly turned up at Beijing's main airport just hours before their first concert and flew back to Pyongyang. They were due to play three shows to help improve ties between China and North Korea. It is not yet clear why the performances were cancelled. Moranbong is one of North Korean pop bands. Its members were handpicked by the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, himself. It plays a mixture of Western and traditional Korean tunes, and has been happy to perform the theme from the film Rocky alongside patriot songs praising North Korea's communist rulers. Its members play a range of instruments, including electronic violins. In their morally conservative home country, the Moranbong musicians are also known for wearing revealing outfits and sporting fashionable hairstyles. The women were waved off for their first-ever foreign tour from Pyongyang railway station on Wednesday by senior leaders. Dressed in military uniforms, they smiled and waved to fans when they came and went from their hotel after arriving in China. Article: In August 2011 he stood victorious inside Col Muammar Gaddafi's Bab al-Aziziya compound after fighters from his Tripoli Brigade broke through the defences of the ousted leader's fortress. But the victory was a long time coming for the staunch anti-Gaddafi fighter, who spent seven years in the city's notorious Abu Selim prison, where he says he was regularly tortured.  He says he and his wife, Fatima Bouchar, were handed to the Gaddafi regime by the CIA after being arrested in Thailand and transported via UK-controlled Diego Garcia. Now he is taking legal action against former British Foreign Secretary Jack Straw over claims that Mr Straw signed papers authorising the move. It is thought to be the first time civil action of this kind has been taken against a former foreign secretary.   Mr Belhadj had fought against Col Gaddafi for many years and had been involved with an Islamist group's attempt to overthrow the Libyan leader in the late 1990s. Mr Belhadj is taking legal action against former British Foreign Secretary Jack Straw over claims that Mr Straw signed papers authorising the move.
It is thought to be the first time civil action of this kind has been taken against a former foreign secretary.
Mr Belhadj - known in the jihadi world as Abu Abdullah al-Sadiq - commanded the now defunct Libyan Islamic Fighting Group (LIFG).
The group was formed in 1990 by Islamist Libyans who had fought in Afghanistan against Soviet forces in the 1980s.
The LIFG waged a three-year low-level insurgency mainly based in eastern Libya, and staged three attempts to assassinate Col Gaddafi in 1995 and 1996, according to Middle East analyst Omar Ashour of Exeter University.
By 1998, the group was crushed. Most of its leaders fled to Afghanistan and joined forces with the Taliban. There, Mr Belhadj is alleged to have developed "close relationships" with al-Qaeda leaders and Taliban chief Mullah Omar, according to an arrest

Hi Kat, A C grade is the minimum required by most colleges that I am aware of, however you may still get a place on an A level course if you wish to. An alternative qualification for entry would be either to continue with your studies at GCSE level and progress onto an A level course if the extra study, knowledge and understanding you gain is sufficient evidence that you are able to work at A level. Or you might instead consider an applied or vocational course at level 3, of which there are many to choose from within the creative industry such as dance, theatre or a related field. College courses give you the opportunity to progress onto university through a HND, HNC or foundation degree, so might be an alternative route for you if your intention is to continue your studies in the future. Please visit https://www.nwconnect.ac.uk/ and choose your local college to find course details and entry requirements.

There is no minimum grade set by college for A levels, but in some cases college requires students to have studied the subject before (this is the case of many science A level courses). Please contact your local college and speak to their course leaders to see if they will accept your D grade or not.```

Caglar continues by pointing out that the number of people who will read the IEEE paper is much smaller than those of the ArXiv, and that while the IEEE is publishing 14 papers, they have published some 1.2k+ papers this past year. I would like to point out that it seems to me that the people who are interested in computer security are mostly not interested in the papers themselves, but in the underlying system, and there has not been a lot of research on this since the 1960s. To my mind, there are a number of reasons for this: the computer science field is largely dominated by the computer science departments at elite institutions, and those in the field today can only view the field in terms of the way that their graduate coursework is taught. ### Commentary

This article, published on the front page of the Washington Post's main Health section (April 21), appears to promote advocacy actions regarding World Malaria Day and the Rollback Malaria Initiative. Specific actions are not specified, but the author calls for "a pledged money for nets, anti-malarial treatments and research for a vaccine" - a fundraising effort. The initiative is said to "raise awareness of the disease and efforts to control malaria around the world."

This particular article was chosen because it appears to promote advocacy actions that are not supported by science. The advocates' own statements suggest that the purpose of these advocacy actions is

Malaria is preventable and curable and yet every 30 seconds, a child in sub-Saharan Africa dies from the disease.” “Last year on April 25, the World Malaria Day initiative was launched to raise awareness of the disease and efforts to control malaria around the world.``` Any questions about this submission should be directed to its author, who is solely responsible for this article or project. Please use the public evaluation form to ask for changes or offer thoughts about how to make this resource more useful.

Roll Back Malaria is a global campaign established in 1998 by the United Nations, the World Bank and the World Health Organization, as part of a Global Millennium Project. The goal of the partnership is to control malaria by reducing malaria deaths by 50% by 2010 through the implementation of strategies to control, prevent and treat malaria. April 25 is the World Malaria Day established by the Roll Back Malaria partnership to bring attention to global malaria issues, the ongoing efforts to eliminate the disease and the resources needed to fight it. Malaria is a preventable and treatable disease caused by parasites transferred to people through the bite of infected mosquitoes. People suffering from malaria typically develop high fevers and severe flu symptoms, and in severe cases they develop coma and experience multiple organ failure and death. A vaccine to prevent malaria has been researched and developed by Glaxo Smithkline and was tested in 1987 in an African field trial in Tanzania and Malawi. The vaccine did not prevent malaria in adults or young children but in children older than 5 years old the vaccine prevented 30% of clinical malaria cases.

The article discusses World Malaria Day, which is held on April 25 to raise awareness of malaria, an often-deadly disease preventable and curable that has plagued every country except Antarctica, and to generate funding to eradicate it. However, despite the disease being preventable, it continues to be a public health threat, with 2015 statistics revealing that it disproportionately affects those in developing countries, causing an estimated 584,000 deaths. In 2000, WHO Member States had committed to reducing deaths from malaria, HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis by 2015. This article discusses how the international community pledged money to combat the malaria epidemic by donating funds towards treatments and a vaccine. The World Health Organization established the Roll Back Malaria strategic framework, which aims to reduce child and maternal malaria-related deaths. The article also examines initiatives like the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, which has supported malaria programs that have impacted more than 700 million people and saved more than 6 million lives.

The Roll Back Malaria partnership was pledged money for nets, anti malarial treatments and research for a vaccine. Last year on April 25, the World Malaria Day initiative was launched to raise awareness of the disease and efforts to control malaria around the world, as part of the Roll Back Malaria partnership.```

The 111 service, replacing NHS Direct, is being piloted in many regions but has proved problematic, with some callers left on hold for hours. Dr Laurence Buckman, the British Medical Association's GP committee chair, says wider rollout should be stalled. The Department of Health says it is giving some areas extra time. It has already sanctioned an extension of up to six months of the original 1 April 2013 deadline for regions struggling to set up the new service. The 111 service will continue to be available to callers in areas where the NHS 111 service is not yet available. The British Medical Association is concerned that many of the places that are already offering the new service or that are due to launch soon are ill-prepared, putting patients' lives at risk. The BMA says it has been receiving widespread reports of NHS 111 failures. Some of the pilot regions have been unable to cope with call volumes or have suffered catastrophic IT failures. In Greater Manchester the entire system crashed, meaning calls went unanswered. One elderly patient had to wait 90 minutes for a call back from NHS 111

• The NHS 111 service is a non-emergency number replacing previous information lines such as NHS Direct 0845 4647
    • It is free to call from landlines but mobile users can be charged, due to the 0845 number
    • Dr Laurence Buckman, the British Medical Association's GP committee chair, says wider rollout should be stalled
    • The Department of Health insists NHS Direct 0845 4647 will continue to be available to callers in areas where the NHS 111 service is not yet available
    • These include: North of Tyne and Tees, North Essex, Bedfordshire and Luton, Cambridgeshire and Peterborough, Leicestershire and Rutland, Berkshire, Cornwall and Devon.

Scientists analyse incredible images of comet 67P using data from the Rosetta spacecraft. US and European scientists analysed images from the Rosetta spacecraft to reveal new details about the comet's shape, evolution and interior. The images included boulder-strewn, smooth Hapi region in the Neck of a cliff face named Hathor, dark boulders in the Imhotep region, and patches of bright frost. The Neck section of the comet contained a small pyramid-shaped feature, known as the "Wing", which lies at the centre of the neck. They may have been "eaten away" over time, rather than being the result of two smaller bodies merging together.

The comet was named 67P after its two Soviet discoverers. It first passed by the Sun in 1996, and was the target for the Rosetta Mission. We have found the first direct evidence of water on the nucleus of comet 67P, which points to water being trapped on the surface. In fact, the comet may be much fluffier than previously thought. Our new data also indicates the comet may be more volcanically active than initially thought. The comet is also covered in ice, with the highest concentrations being on the 'smooth' areas. Interestingly, the comet's 'smooth' areas, are in fact bouldor strewn regions. The comet's neck is much rougher than anticipated. The comet appears to have two 'lobes', which may indicate that two smaller comets have merged together. The neck may in fact have been 'eaten away' over time. The overall surface of the comet is very dark. This is probably the result of the comet being much more active in the distant past.

US President Obama took a humorous, playful approach in delivering the final State of the Union speech of his nearly 2-term presidency on Tuesday (28 Jan).  In this 78-minute address, the President outlined the state of the country and addressed an array of contentious topics including healthcare, education, climate, energy, terrorism, racism, sexism, LGBT discrimination, immigration, economic inequality, middle class, minimum wage, manufacturing, free trade agreements, and global power.   This speech was widely described as one of the most personal and emotional of his White House tenure as the President focused on the changes and impact his Administration has carried out during the past 7 years and the achievements and gains of the country over the past 8 years.

Virginia Nguyen, who has denied stealing an iPad belonging to a critically ill patient at the hospital where she was a medical student, has just been charged with two felonies -- grand theft and computer fraud.

The latest developments come after the LA District Attorney declined to press charges against 32-year-old Nguyen, also a veteran of the US Navy, NBC Los Angeles reported.

In February, an iPad belonging to a patient who subsequently died at Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center went missing and it was later determined that it was stolen by another patient in the same ward.

My name is Nicole Nelson-Packer; I am Natalie Packer’s sister.

My daughter and I were in the hospital the day my sister passed away. We were at her bedside the whole time. My sister went into cardiac arrest early in the morning around 4am. I am not the best.

"She is (a) fully qualified, highly trained, combat ready pilot, and she led the mission," Yousef Al Otaiba told MSNBC's "Morning Joe."   The UAE has joined the United States and a handful of other Arab nations in conducting airstrikes against ISIS in Syria. This summer, the group declared the establishment of a "caliphate," an Islamic state stretching across the territory it has conquered.   It maintains strict rules for women, who are lashed for infractions such as not being fully covered.   Al Otaiba said the campaign against ISIS basically boils down to the question of what type of society one wants. This is a threat against us. This is more of a threat against us than it is against you. This is not just a threat to our countries. This is a threat to our way of life," the ambassador told MSNBC. CNN spoke to Al Mansouri earlier this year about her work. She had wanted to be a fighter pilot since she finished high school, but had to wait until women were allowed. "At that time, the doors were not open for females to be pilots. So I had to wait almost 10 years for the decision to be taken," Al Mansouri said. She stressed there's no difference between men and women when it comes to defending their country. "We are in a hot area so that we have to prepare every citizen," Al Mansouri said. . Emily Crane . A young man has admitted to setting a teenager alight in a garage and causing him such horrific burns he had to be placed in a coma. Joshua William Lomas, 21, pleaded guilty in the Adelaide Magistrates Court on Wednesday to causing serious harm to Luke Coburn, now 18,  in the garage of the teenager's home, north of Adelaide, in January 2013. Luke's mother, Cheryl Coburn, said outside court that Lomas had chosen to target Luke because he was jealous her son had started dating a girl he liked. ```

SUMMARY:
Lomas, 21, of Munno Para West, pleaded guilty in the Adelaide Magistrates Court to causes serious harm to Luke Coburn on 9 January 2013, and was remanded to stand sentence on 26 September in the district court.

BACKGROUND:
Luke had been 16 years old at the time, and was at the home of a friend when the pair were approached by Lomas, one of two people who set fire to Luke by pouring a flammable liquid over him.

Luke sustained third-degree burns to his ears, neck and arms. He was hospitalised for five weeks, where he had to undergo a skin graft surgery.

Luke says that the reason he was chosen was because the attacker was jealous of his girlfriend.

IMPLICATIONS:
A statement regarding Mr. Coburn's attacker and friend has been made, but the statement was not released in court. It is still unknown who Luke's other attacker was.

A new mother's cervical cancer went undiagnosed for 14 months because doctors thought the symptoms were related to her pregnancy.

Shelley Maye,  from Newbury, Berkshire, had been suffering from extreme tiredness, back ache, bleeding after intercourse and sickness.

But it wasn't until her baby, Jenson, was four- months-old, that the 34-year-old received the devastating news that she had advanced cervical cancer.

The mother-of-two was told the disease had already spread to the surrounding tissue and a hysterectomy would no longer work as there was not enough healthy tissue to perform the operation.

A family returned to their home town to see the damage to their house after flooding. They heard the faint callings of a cat trapped in the attic. It took a team of 4 firemen to rescue the trapped animal. The cat was reunited with its owner but had suffered a broken leg.

The 46-year-old who lost 10 ounces in a day on a 400-calorie diet: "How is this healthy?" says Dr. Oz . “Everything you eat adds weight to your body. When you eat a carrot or potato, for example, your stomach digests the starch first , and then sends the sugar to your bloodstream. Then your body says, 'Oh, my God, I have all this sugar!' So it pumps out insulin in response to the sugar, and in response to insulin, your body says, 'Oh, I've made enough insulin, let's send the calories to our fat stores.' In other words, whatever you eat can potentially end up in your fat. “If you're doing a 400-calorie diet, your body sends everything to your fat cells, and you don't get full. So you still hunger for food. You're basically eating too much. “When you take a 400-calorie diet and add a gallon of water, what happens is all the sugar gets metabolized, and you get full from the water. “The idea of a

Pancreatic cancer patients who are obese may be 12 times more likely to have cancer that's already spread to their lymph nodes at the time of surgery than similar cancer patients who weigh less, according to a study released Monday in the Archives of Surgery. In the study, 95 percent of patients with a BMI over 35 had a recurrence compared with 61 percent of other patients. "What we are seeing suggests there is a difference in the way the cancer grows in obese patients versus those who are not," says study author Jason B. Fleming, M.D., of the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. "That is an area, from a biology standpoint, that has not really been explored." ```

Obesity linked to advanced stage pancreatic cancer   Pancreatic cancer patients with a high body mass index tend to have advanced-stage tumors at the time of diagnosis (American Cancer Society, 2012). An analysis of medical records of patients who had surgery to remove some or all of the pancreas for pancreatic cancer between 2001 and 2011 found that those with a body mass index greater than 35 (more than 223 pounds for someone who is 5' 6") were less likely to get chemotherapy or radiation before surgery, and they were less likely than normal-weight patients to achieve the goal of surgical removal of tumor (J. B. Curator Torsten Opper says: "No matter what our take is on the conflict in Iraq today, we can relate to Hadrian's decision. Maybe 10 or 15 years ago, it wouldn't have mattered so much. Now it does." Hadrian was born in Rome to a noble family whose origins lay in Spain. Article: In the jittery days that have followed the violent clashes between Lebanon's army and fighters loyal to the radical Sunni preacher Sheikh Ahmad al-Assir, the army has two urgent tasks.
The first is to find Mr Assir, who managed to melt away as soldiers stormed the apartment block he had turned into a fortress in the heart of a residential district in the southern city of Sidon.
The second - and more important - task is to reassure an increasingly anxious Lebanese public that it has the capacity to restore calm and maintain order.
It is no surprise that Mr Assir has been the catalyst that has set off the chain of military and political reactions which has left the Lebanese army facing perhaps its most testing week since neighbouring Syria erupted into civil war.
You can trace the sheikh's rapid evolution from fiery, if rather eccentric, radical Sunni preacher to militia leader in fragments of video widely shown on TV here.
In older footage, there are amusing stunts in which the smiling sheikh takes busloads of his followers onto a ski slope. The cultural message was heavy-handed but harmless, even charming

- 4. And finally, it showed the country's Shia militant group, Hezbollah, that the army, not Mr Assir's militia, had the upper hand in south Lebanon.
- 5. But most ominously, Saturday's battle in Tripoli saw the use of helicopters, and it might only be the beginning of yet another phase in a regional conflict, with the threat of a civil in Lebanon.

# The researchers found that Painted Ladies are able to sense the wind and migrate between the UK and Europe by flying according to the wind direction. The butterflies migrate across Europe to the UK, but instead of wintering in the UK, they migrate to southern Africa for the winter where their pupae (cocoon) spend the winter. # On their return, they fly from southern Africa back to Europe via the UK, taking advantage of the warmer air that is carried aloft by the jet stream. # Using trapping stations all over the UK and on the Continent, and radar at the British Antarctic Survey in Rothera, the researchers were able to track the butterflies for three years, and in doing so, discovered that the Painted Ladies are not just an occasional

Painted Lady butterflies make an epic intergenerational migration that stretches 6,000 miles each way. Painted Lady butterflies make a spectacularly long journey each summer from breeding grounds in Africa to their overwintering sites further north in Europe. They cross the Mediterranean to breed in the Mediterranean basin, and make a return journey heading north to Britain in July, sometimes in staggering numbers, like in 1992, when one million landed at St Austell in Cornwall, where they stayed for two days. From there they are seen heading north all over the country, including in my back garden. A Painted Lady butterfly sits atop lilac flowers. Painted Lady Factsheet The Painted Lady (Vanessa cardui) is a small migratory butterfly, up to 33 mm in length, with a wingspan of up to 45 mm . It has a variable appearance and can be brown, greenish or orange/yellow in colour. The sexes are similar. Up to six generations are produced in the temperate north, but only two or three in more southerly latitudes. The butterfly migrates to the north in the spring and to the south in the autumn. In Europe the butterfly is found locally in most countries except Germany, Poland, Scandinavia and most of the British Isles. ``` _more summaries available!

# The Migration of Painted Lady Butterflies!

- The Painted Lady is a beautiful summer butterfly which has a distinctive black tail with a white edge and two orange bands across the black wings. It is considered by some to be Britain’s favourite butterfly. Its Latin name is Vanessa cardui and it is often referred to as the Thaime (also spelt Thyme!) by many. The Painted Lady is a member of the Nymphalidae, or brush-footed butterfly family. This family is characterised by the way it walks by having the forelegs adapted with stiff hairs and pads so it can grip things like bramble stalks to climb with ease.

`Plaid Cymru leader Adam Price has accused other AMs of 'sneering' at the party's call to close the investment gap between West Wales and South Wales. In a row over the Welsh finance secretary's budget speech, Mr Price said investment in mid and west Wales would be less than 30% by the end of the current financial year. Mr Price said his party was trying to "equalise the level of investment across Wales". Lee Waters, who represents South Wales West, warned against "pork barrel" budget deals that include bypass projects. On Tuesday's budget, Mr Price claimed the Welsh government's capital spending in mid and west Wales would be less than £1,000 per person, while spending in the Valleys would top £3,000. Plaid secured £30m for a bypass in its constituency when it supported the budget. It was Mr Price's tweet about the bypass that provoked a sharp rebuke from Mr Waters. Asked if he regretted the tweet, Mr Price said he didn't but "regretted the attitude". ````

## What is cancer?

Cancer is the uncontrollable growth and spread of cells in the body. These cells are called tumors and are generally found in the brain or the bone, but can also develop in blood vessels, the liver, the pancreas, the lungs, the ovaries, and the kidneys. They can also be found in the skin, bladder, prostate, stomach, bowel, and the bladder.

## What causes cancer?

The majority of people with cancer develop it through lifestyle factors. Some of these include:
1) Smoking
2) Alcohol
3) Infection
4) Vitamin C

## Is there a cure for cancer?

Amy Robach considers her job as news anchor on Good Morning America a much-needed distraction from her chemotherapy treatments, sources have said. The 41-year-old, who has just taken over the anchor role following the prompt departure of Josh Elliott last week, has just completed the sixth of eight treatments to battle breast cancer. She underwent the treatment last week and was back at work the next day. Fighter: Amy Robach, pictured left with fellow GMA anchor Lara Spencer, is turning to work to distract her from her chemotherapy treatments following her breast cancer diagnosis last year. 'Amy considers getting up every morning and having something to look forward to a gift,' a source told People magazine. 'It's a much-needed distraction from her treatment.' Robach, a mother to two young girls and a step-mother to three boys, was diagnosed with breast cancer five months ago after undergoing a mammogram for the show. She discovered she had a . malignant tumor in her right breast and it was only after she had a double mastectomy soon after that . doctors realized there was a second tumor in the same breast and some . abnormal cells in the left

This year breast cancer affected 1.3 million people globally, 1 in 8 women and . 1 in 100 men in the U.S. alone. Amy Robach, a mother of two young girls and a step-mother of three boys, was diagnosed with breast cancer last year, about five months before Good Morning America. Her diagnosis was made public during an on-air mammogram, and she has been the subject of several GMA stories since, as well as giving interviews to other news shows and magazines. When she learned she had breast cancer, she decided to go public because she saw a gap in the knowledge and communication of the disease and needed more information.

Robach was recently named the co-anchor to GMA alongside George Stephanopoulos; however, she has been reporting on the daily show for the past several months and it was previously known that she would be replacing Josh Elliott, who left the show abruptly last month. Robach continues to appear on the main show and on World News Now, reporting her usual news stories.

However, Robach has undergone a mastectomy, found abnormal cells in her breasts and lymph nodes and continues to see doctors

President Obama on Wednesday signed a law that makes it a federal crime to assault an individual because of his or her sexual orientation or gender identity. The expanded federal hate crimes law, hailed by supporters as the first major federal gay rights legislation, was added to a $680 billion defense authorization bill that Obama signed at a packed White House ceremony. The hate crimes measure was named for Matthew Shepard, a gay Wyoming teenager who died after being kidnapped and severely beaten in October 1998, and James Byrd Jr., an African-American man dragged to death in Texas the same year. Shepard's mother, Judy, was among those at the ceremony that also included Vice President Joe Biden, Defense Secretary Robert Gates, Attorney General Eric Holder and leading members of Congress and the Pentagon, who were on hand for the appropriations bill signing. To loud applause, Obama hailed the hate crimes measure in the bill as a step toward change to "help protect our citizens from violence based on what they look like, who they love, how they pray." People Don't Know the Human Body

(BMC FamilyPractice)

by Raphael Garcia, Staff Writer

HealthDay Review, June 21, 2008

``` If home is where the heart is, a new survey suggests that most people aren't sure exactly where they live.

More than half of people cannot pinpoint the exact location of the human heart on a diagram, and nearly 70 percent can't correctly identify the shape of the lungs, according to the survey.

This lack of knowledge isn't just embarrassing -- it could lead to a poorer quality of health care, some experts say.

In the study, published in the journal BMC Family Practice, a research team surveyed 722 Britons -- 589 hospital outpatients and 133 people in the general population. They gave the volunteers four diagrams of human figures and asked them to choose the one that showed the correct size and location of a specific organ. (For example, the heart diagrams showed various size organs on the far left side of the chest, directly in the center, anchored on the center/left

text The knowledge of anatomy is not essential for many aspects of our everyday life. However, the understanding of our body can influence the quality of healthcare or our knowledge about the physiology of our body. Aim: To find out whether knowledge about major human body parts has improved or declined over the past 30 years. Methods: 722 subjects were randomly selected. A questionnaire was developed to measure the awareness about eight body parts (the heart, lungs, stomach, thyroid, pancreas, kidneys, bladder, and brain) out of the 589 participants recruited from hospital outpatient departments, and 133 subjects from the general population. Subjects were presented with four drawings depicting the size and position of each body part within a frontal view of a human body in various positions (e.g. an organ drawn in the middle of the left chest cavity, an organ on the far left, and an organ on the right-hand side). The position was drawn incorrectly if the organ was either too large or too small and/or positioned inaccurately. Results: 80.7% of subjects were able to correctly identify the bladder, followed

`German football governing body DFB hit out at Borussia Dortmund on Sunday for the behaviour of its ultras at the club's Champions League fixture at home to Leipzig. Fans held up offensive banners during a 1-0 win over RB Leipzig and lit flares, while there were reports of crowd trouble outside the Westfalenstadion. The German Football Association (DFB) said Dortmund "needs to be sanctioned". The club has until Monday to accept the proposal or reject it in which case the decision will be taken by DFB's court. Dortmund had received a suspended sentence last summer for similar offences and the DFB said there had been trouble at three other games this season - against Mainz, Hoffenheim, and the away game in Leipzig. Banners at Saturday's game attacked Leipzig, owned by energy drink makers Red Bull, as well as their sports director Ralf Rangnick and Red Bull owner Dieter Mateschitz "Slaughter the bulls," read one. Dortmund has already promised to crack down on fan violence and the club said it "deeply regrets" last weekend's violence that also left police officers and a police dog injured

triathlete Alistair Brownlee has continued to impress at the 2016 ITU World Triathlon Series on home soil in Leeds and with younger brother Jonny in second it was the result that the huge crowds in their home city of Leeds had wanted.
Britain's Vicky Holland had earlier taken third in the women's race to underline her own medal chances in Rio.

* Use direct quotes when appropriate.

* Don't use the text itself in a quote.

* Don't have any grammar or spelling errors.```

Health officials declined to say whether the three were students or teachers. They also said they did not know what strain of TB the three contracted.

The Fairfax County, Virginia, health department is investigating a tuberculosis outbreak at an area school after three people tested positive for the potentially fatal bacteria, officials said Thursday. The health department has contacted 430 people who may have been exposed and need to be tested as a result of exposure to the three, the officials said. Health officials declined to say whether the three were students or teachers. They also said they did not know what strain of TB the three contracted. The first case of tuberculosis at Robert E. Lee High School was diagnosed in December 2012, and the health department opened and completed an investigation, the agency said. But because two more people from the same school were diagnosed with it in June, the department re-opened the December case and is investigating whether they are related. TB bacteria usually attack the lungs, but they can also attack other parts of the body such as the kidneys, spine and brain, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. If not treated properly, TB can be fatal.```

The article presents a news brief about a Tuberculosis outbreak in Virginia. Fairfax County in Virginia has reported three people testing positive for tuberculosis (TB). The affected people are three out of 430 people who may have been exposed to the disease. Health officials have not revealed the identities of the infected persons. However, they have stated that the TB infection was detected in December 2012 and an investigation was opened and closed soon after. The outbreak has prompted a health department to intervene and investigate the matter. Health officials stated that it is difficult to determine whether the new cases are related to the older case. TB is a contagious bacterial disease that mostly affects the lungs. If untreated, it can lead to death. Health officials have advised people affected by the disease to get tested so that a proper treatment can be started to prevent the disease from spreading among the infected people. People with compromised immune systems, such as infants and young children, the elderly, and people with serious health conditions, are at higher risk of developing TB infection. The article further highlights the importance of timely treatment to prevent the spread of the disease.

Chimps were chosen, rather than gorillas, because they are physiologically more similar to humans, and so the vaccine's safety was more closely modelled on humans.
The vaccine, which had been tested on humans before, was given through an injection into the back of their neck.
The scientists then waited to see if it caused any problems - from swelling round the injection site to allergies or fevers.
They found that the animals did have immune responses in the first few days after vaccination but no "adverse events" on the day or in the following days, and no one was found to have antibodies to the Ebola virus before the trial vaccination.
This finding, say the scientists, suggests that the vaccine will pose no risk to humans or apes.
So, if the vaccine could be given to gorillas, could it help them?

  A video of a British violinist playing Bachs concerto and a clip of a French cellist playing Paganini were enough for them to make the top 116 candidates to be the world's first YouTube Symphony Orchestra.

Markets make winners out of losers Leeds United have enjoyed a brilliant season so far, are top of the Championship and have a decent chance of ending their 11-year exile from the Premier League next season. They could go further and get into the Premier League by winning automatic promotion. However, it could all come crashing down when the Football League rule-makers slap them with a transfer ban in the New Year. This is a very fair and important rule - one that was clearly needed when you look at the fact that the two most successful clubs in the Premier League in the last three seasons were Chelsea and Manchester City, who have spend hundreds of millions of pounds to make sure that they stay in the rich English top flight - but for this rule to be effective the punishment has to be fair and effective. A ban on transfer activity in the final months of the regular season is a major blow, for obvious reasons, because the squads were already made when they were banned. Jones was not in favor of the Iran rescue mission. When his recommendation to postpone was rejected by Carter, he reportedly went to work drafting his resignation.

Jones was also reportedly out of favor with President Reagan at different times, including being replaced as the chairman, after he clashed with Reagan's chief of staff Donald Rumsfeld and defense secretary Cap Weinberger (who subsequently served in the same role under the younger Bush). Jones was also out of favor with Carter for his reluctance to take the rescue mission forward, and he reportedly had to accept the job in Weinberger's Defense Department as Chief of Staff after his plan to retire was disrupted by his wife's terminal illness.

Jones is described as quiet and unassuming, but also as tough and stubborn, with a strong sense of fairness. He was reportedly able to be very blunt with the president, without losing their respect.

Today, London is on fire. Rioters are setting blazes, hurling stones, beating up famous statues and some of them kicked Prince Charles' car. Which is a little like beating up a statue, but still... Students have come unhinged over a plan to triple university fees. The government says it had to approve the increase to fight soaring budget problems. As Americans, of course, we're quite different from the Brits in many ways. But our young people certainly have this in common: here, as there, tuition rates have steadily risen, job opportunities for graduates have grown more scarce, and the prospects of maintaining the "good life" so many younger folks enjoy now have dimmed. And history has shown time and again, that when young people get upset they have a nasty tendency to take it to the streets. Which has me wondering if maybe we're setting the stage for similar unrest here on the American side of the pond. We have a deficit problem. We're talking about hefty cuts of services and/or tax increases. And we always seem to have reasonable numbers of disaffected youth, no matter how many iPhones we buy for them.

Production fell 1.1% in September from the previous month, the country's statistics agency Destatis said.
The fall was a surprise, with some economists expecting industrial output to rise.
A slowdown in some emerging markets had weighed production down, Germany's economy ministry said.
"After a good development in the first half, German industry is currently experiencing a light headwind from the world economy, in particular due to a slowdown in some large emerging markets," the ministry said.
In a three-month comparison, factories produced 0.3% fewer goods in the July-to-September period, with an increase in construction not fully offsetting a fall in manufacturing output.

Girl Scouts' membership drops 6 percent
By NICOLE WINFIELD
AP National Writer

1 November 2014, Wednesday
Associated Press

``` "

For the second straight year, youth and adult membership in the Girl Scouts has dropped sharply, intensifying pressure on the 102-year-old youth organization to find ways of reversing the trend.
   According to figures provided to The Associated Press, the total of youth members and adult volunteers dropped by 6 percent over the past year — from 2,994,844 to 2,813,997. Over two years, total membership is down 11.6 percent, and it has fallen 27 percent from a peak of more than 3.8 million in 2003.
   While the Girl Scouts of the USA have had an array of recent internal difficulties — including rifts over programming and serious fiscal problems — CEO Anna Maria Chavez attributed the membership drop primarily to broader societal factors that have affected many youth-serving organizations.
   ``Parents and families are less financially stable, frequently working two

http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2015/04/17/girl-scouts-membership/25949199/  "In hopes of stemming the drop, the Girl Scouts are revamping their online platforms with new resources, including revising its marketing and recruitment strategies, streamlining the ­process of joining the Girl Scouts, and providing online toolkits — one to help streamline recruiting, planning, and record-keeping for troop leaders; another to provide an online, ­customizable yearlong plan for all ­meetings and activities."  "The organization has also been making concerted efforts ­recently to attract girls of different races and economic backgrounds in an effort to better reflect American diversity.'' ```

Article: Japanese plastic surgeon Katsuya Takasu had promised to reward the team after hearing about their financial difficulties before and during the tournament.

Takasu fulfilled his promise by presenting cheques of $200,000 and $190,000 to coach Samson Siasia and captain John Mikel Obi respectively on behalf of the team.

He met with them two hours after Nigeria defeated Honduras 3-2 in the bronze medal play-off.

“The $200,000 covers the bonuses and allowances as promised and the $190,000 is for the bronze medal,” Takasu told BBC Sport.

“I had travelled from Tokyo prepared to reward them anyway, and to watch them win the bronze inside the stadium was very fulfilling,” he added.

Before arriving in Rio, Nigeria’s ‘Dream Team VI’ were held up in Atlanta, USA, because of a problem with the payment for their flight, and they only landed in Brazil just hours before their opening 5-4 win over Japan.

Clarke will, by now, have heard the comments from the Chairman, but in fact this is a message on two fronts.
Coventry have one of the oldest League One squads and the average age of the forwards is a whopping 30 years, a good five years over average. That is not going to be improved by losing Clarke.
