Abell replaces Chris Rogers as skipper, following the former Australia Test opener's retirement in September. He has played 32 first-class matches since his debut in 2014, averaging 31.37 and scoring three centuries. Somerset finished second in County Championship Division One in 2016, narrowly missing out on a maiden title. Middlesex became champions on a thrilling final day as they dramatically beat Yorkshire at Lord's. “People will no doubt point out Tom’s age but that doesn’t come in to it,” director of cricket Matt Maynard told Somerset’s website. “If you’re good enough, you’re old enough – and Tom is certainly good enough. `` I believe a lot of the issues with the US healthcare system are due to the vast differences in what people pay for insurance. The majority of people with insurance in the US have their health care paid for by their employer . That's why when an insurance company refuses to cover a certain diagnosis or procedure, it isn't really an issue that affects the majority of people . When people have to pay for their insurance, they will research to find the best deal, to the the issue that may or may not be relevant to them, and to find a different provider if necessary. On the other hand, when the majority of people's health care is paid for, those who are having difficulty paying can appeal to the government to provide them with health care, which in turn encourages the government to try to provide health care at least as good as the private insurance companies that they already have . But if they can't find a way to provide it at a higher level, they will continue to increase the taxes and fees that people have to pay, so that the majority of people will be forced to use a lower quality of care . `````

BBC News - Bishop remembers child graves in Lancashire reburial

The Bishop of Blackburn says it is a "privilege" to be with the Lancashire community on the reburial of around 800 children in a park in Blackburn, who died at the turn of the 19th century.

The 1,967 bodies were excavated from 200 graves at St Peter's church as the site is redeveloped.

The Bishop of Blackburn Rt Rev Julian Henderson said during the service it was a "privilege" to rebury the bodies.

The service took place in the memorial garden containing the graves.

## Bodies of 800 children discovered in Blackburn

The Bishop of Blackburn dedicated a memorial garden at Wainwright Way

The skeletal remains of an estimated 1,967 people including 800 children were unearthed during work to build a road in Blackburn.

The bodies were discovered in January during work to build the Freckleton Street link road.

A service led by the Bishop of Blackburn to mark the reburial of the remains has been held in the town.

An estimated 1,700 remains were reburied at Wainwright Garden of Remembrance last year.

Four months of excavations uncovered 489 adults, 1,077 children and four babies at the now disused burial site, which once served a church called St Peter's.

About 200 bodies were not buried because of poor condition of the bone.

Bishops will be having a meeting on Tuesday and decide on the way forward.

"So they would have to discuss among themselves what would be the best thing to do, because it's a very difficult balancing act, to try to give some sense of fairness to this whole issue, and that is what they would be discussing, that's where we are now.

The HSE is planning to implement an online doctor triage and advice service for patients. There are currently plans for a pilot of the service which will involve patients contacting the triage service by phone. HSE has not decided if a GP or nurse will initially speak to patients or if the patients will initially be spoken to by an AI voice programme. The service would allow the public to “self-triage”.

Nurses have criticised the online nurse/doctor triage and advice service for patients as another way of delivering services through a digital platform.

They have warned that this service will not improve access and will be delivered in a “digital desert” because the HSE has failed to build infrastructure across the country.

Nurses and midwives say that GPs and other healthcare professionals need to be fully integrated into any new service to determine if people should be referred to the Emergency Department. They warn that digital systems require real-time monitoring for safety risk and say that they need to have the skills to manage and analyse data. They cite a study which found the digital health system has “reliability and safety issues” because of inadequate oversight by clinicians.

The verdicts were announced in Afghanistan capital Kabul on Wednesday, nearly six months after Farkhunda was beaten, stoned and burned alive in a street incident in the city. Earlier today Afghan Judicial officials said that the verdicts on the main suspects in the case would be announced in courts, according to Xinhua news agency. Farkhunda was stoned, beaten and burned alive on March 19 after she was falsely accused of burning or desecrating a Quran. In the wake of her death, thousands of people took to the streets in some of the biggest protests seen by Afghan capital city in years, calling for the execution of the attackers. Her death was recorded on video by local media, and the amateur footage went viral, drawing outrage and disgust from people around the world. While the official investigator in the case said on Wednesday that the video footage had been used as evidence. The Afghan Independent Human Rights Commission (AIHRC) has hailed the sentencing of those linked to the death of Farkhunda, describing it as an important step to uphold the rule of law in the conflict-torn country. The 28-year-old woman called Farkhunda was beaten to death after being accused of burning a copy of the Koran, although witnesses say she did not.
It took just four days for the verdicts to be reached. Eight men were sentenced to 16 years in prison and 18 others found not guilty.
The incident led to widespread protests against the treatment of women.
A decision in the case of 19 policemen accused of failing in their duty to prevent the attack is expected on Sunday.
Farkhunda had argued with an amulet seller about his practice of peddling charms to women at the well-known Shah-Du-Shamshaira shrine, which is within walking distance of the presidential palace and Kabul's main bazaar.
The amulet seller is one of those sentenced to death on Wednesday.
In the course of the argument Farkhunda was accused of burning the Koran and a crowd overheard and attacked her.

Health chiefs say a register would alert GPs to the specific needs of adults and children with autism and help tailor services for them. The National Autistic Society said it would "help improve the health and wellbeing of autistic people". But getting a quick diagnosis was still an issue, a child autism charity said. Autism is a lifelong, developmental disability that affects how a person communicates with and relates to other people, and how they experience the world around them. GPs in England already keep a register of patients with learning disabilities, and the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence thinks patients with autism should be easily identified by health care professionals too. NICE says a register - which would be anonymous outside a patient's surgery - would help staff to adapt their approach to suit patients' needs. For example, doctors might need to take time to explain information clearly, nurses could vaccinate children at quieter times of the day, and surgeries could turn down lights for those with sensory problems. Robyn Steward, 30, has autism and lives in south London. She says going to the GP can be a difficult experience. "I used to dread ringing up. I have lots

Health experts say having the register would boost the number of autism diagnoses, which has risen from about 1% in 2000 to 2.8% in 2015.
People with the condition can have extreme difficulties with speech and communication and their understanding of what is going on around them.
But they can also be creative and artistic thinkers.
And a lot of people are undiagnosed - a survey of young adults estimated that just 6% of those diagnosed had been so from childhood.
Adults with autism are less likely than others to receive an annual health check and treatment for long-term conditions, says the government.
In England, this NHS screening programme for adults at greatest risk is currently aimed at people with learning disabilities.
That register is based on primary care data, and updated by people with learning disabilities and/or autism when they see health and care professionals.
NICE's guideline on learning disabilities says autism should be included on the register, but it's not routine practice everywhere yet.
It has also developed a "rapid review guide" for primary care organisations to help them set up more targeted screening.

Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States, accounting for nearly 1 of every 4 deaths according to the National Cancer Institute. Because of advances in research and in medicine, however, more people now live longer after they are diagnosed with cancer. More advances continue to be made and offer promise of better treatments in the future.

The number of women who died from cancer and other diseases in the U.S. has increased since 2008, with cancer deaths rising by 1.5%, according to a 2015 annual report on cancer. About 585,390 cancer deaths are expected this year according to the report, which was co-released on Sept

Detection of cancer is often possible only by means of specialized tests and instruments. The early symptoms of cancer are so general and nonspecific that they may be mistaken for signs of other diseases. Cancer may be difficult to treat and is often life-threatening; it is caused by out-of-control cell growth. The uncontrolled growth of cells leads to the destruction of healthy neighboring tissue. Cancer is usually detected by some imaging procedure (such as X-ray examinations or computed tomography scans) or by biopsy. Depending on the type and the severity of the cancer, the growth of the cancerous tissue can be slowed or halted by chemotherapy. Sometimes, particularly with skin cancers, simple excision of the growth is the best treatment. Occasionally, when the growth is extremely small, killing it with heat (cryosurgery) or destroying it with a high-energy beam (radiotherapy) is an option. Cancer can sometimes be completely cured with surgery to remove the cancerous growth. In some forms of cancer, such as leukemia, chemotherapy is the main approach to therapy. To secure a good post-Brexit Trade Agreement with the EU, there are four steps the UK government needs to take. 

Successful negotiations require skilled negotiators backed by a large team, clear goals, a government machine galvanised by strong leadership and communication between national leaders.

These aren't easy to do, but without these tools and mindsets, the UK will struggle to compete at the table with the highly experienced EU negotiators.

A trade deal is the ultimate outcome of diplomacy and trade negotiation between two or more states or blocs. Typically, each side is looking to reduce the tariffs and duties, increase market access and achieve a balance of trade where more imports from the other side are exported to the domestic market. A trade negotiation will likely only commence once there is a strong appetite to do so, for instance when there is a mutual understanding by both sides that a new trade regime will be in their interest. This may be triggered in the event of a perceived threat in the short to mid-term that an existing trade relationship will be disrupted as a result of one or more of the following: · a trade dispute, typically a long-standing issue that has yet to reach a resolution · a significant change in government or government policy · the failure to complete a multilateral trade agreement with several or all WTO-member states · an escalation in the ongoing trade wars/tariff conflicts. In the case of a trade war specifically, one state's economy may have reached the point at which it is no longer considered in its national interests to perpetuate the current trade arrangement; indeed, it may be that it may be in its economic interests to

`````````````` In the case of the UK, negotiations will be with the 27 member states, the European Commission which is the lead negotiator, the European Court of Justice and the European Parliament. This is both a large number of parties and institutions and a complex interrelationship.
As of yet, only four countries the Netherlands, Sweden, Denmark and Greece - have had their parliaments sign off the deal with Canada. As one negotiator put it, “you only have to look to the Canada deal to see we are way down the road”. While it is not the only example, it provides some clue as to the task ahead.
After 43 years’ membership, the UK has yet to finalise agreements with its most important trade partners. Negotiating deals is a complex and politically and legally involved process, so there are good reasons to think that it won’t be easy.
But it has been more than 40 years since the UK last got around the negotiating table and it could be a little rusty. Here are four key requirements to getting a good deal.

It should be noted that Labour are not against cuts, just against excessive cuts. If the coalition government were planning just cuts of 20 or 30 thousand pounds per year, it wouldn't really matter to Labour that much. However, when Labour start talking about 50 thousand pounds per year, we are talking about much more than just cuts, we're talking about a reduction in standards in people's lifestyles, and cuts to services they've come to expect. At this point "cuts" would become "austerity" and Labour would be right to point this out. This could then translate into votes for the Labour Party.

The problem is Labour's lack of economic credibility - something every opinion poll confirms.
The opportunity is the chance to paint the Tories as not merely serious about cutting borrowing but ideologically obsessed with it.
He and Ed Balls believe that their lack of credibility is rooted not in the lack of understanding of their detailed economic policies, but in their perceived inability to say "no" to more spending.

In addition they have said they will clear the deficit as soon as possible - which sounds tough but allows them two or three years more than the current coalition plan.

A homeless man with a glass eye who was arrested on Saturday after police found him camping with a missing 13-year-old girl has been charged with rape, sodomy, sexual abuse and kidnapping. The young teen allegedly kidnapped by Kelsey 'Patrick' McCune, 40, was last seen at her Oregon City home on Tuesday night, with her family pleading her help in finding her following an extensive search last week. It was originally thought she had run away with McCune, a friend of the girl's father with no known address who had spent Thanksgiving with the family. Following a tip from a woman walking her dog, who had recognized the girl from missing persons flyer, the pair were seized upon by a SWAT team sent in to case the area north of the Country Village Mobile Home Park, where the girl lives with her family. Connecticut's governor announced Tuesday that the rail route will resume carrying New Haven-New York commuters by Wednesday, five days after a derailment of one of the nation's busiest rail lines. ```

In Connecticut, those who rely on the train to commute between New Haven and New York will be able to resume their normal travel on Wednesday, more than five days after a derailment occurred on one of the busiest tracks in the country. After the announcement of the resumption of services, Amtrak said it will resume services on the track starting Wednesday, May 20. "This is very, very good news and something that we did not think could be accomplished," Connecticut Gov. Dannel Malloy said in a new conference. Amtrak released a statement shortly after the announcement saying service between Boston and New York will also resume Wednesday. Those who have paid for the travel and choose not to travel can receive a refund or a voucher for future travel, Amtrak said. "Because of the inconvenience, Amtrak said passengers who "have paid but choose not to travel due to this service disruption can receive a refund or a voucher for future travel." According to CNN, more than 30,000 passengers travel this rail corridor daily. ``` ## Key Information

Artur Samarin faces deportation next week on separate charges after enrolling at school in the US under fake name

A 24-year-old Russian citizen is facing deportation next week after enrolling in a high school in Pennsylvania under a pseudonym.

Artur Samarin was arrested in February for having sex with a minor, but now faces the additional charge of having used a false identity to gain entry to the Harrisburg School District.

His visa expired in 2012 and he faces deportation on July 27 under a name he provided to the Department of Homeland Security to gain a work permit.

Samarin reportedly faced no consequences due to a legal loophole regarding a state law known as the Tierney amendment, which requires school districts to deny enrolment to foreigners.

But since Harrisburg School District was closed, it did not have to adhere to the statute, according to the Patriot-News.

The newspaper said Samarin was a very active member of the district who was even involved in its food banks and cadet programmes.

Unison union claims employers Cordia - a body of Glasgow City Council - are refusing to discuss the issues surrounding the strike. It is over additional payments for tasks which the janitors say are "dirty, unpleasant, involve regularly working outside or heavy lifting". Janitors first walked out in March and are set for further action on 20 April. Cordia said they had given Unison three opportunities to outline their issues and that the matter was considered by a committee before being rejected. But Unison said janitors were entitled to the Working Context and Demands Payment which ranges from about £500 to more than £1,000. The BBC has been censured for a breach of its guidelines after 22 complaints over radio dedications show Sunday Love Songs with Steve Wright. Listeners discovered their romantic music requests and personal messages were all pre-recorded – and missed the deadline as the show was recorded on Fridays and scheduled live from 9am on Sundays. It also emerged some listeners were told it was not possible to play their favourites as the show was pre-recorded even though it was still a day before the Sunday show went out on air. BBC guidelines state: "Our pre-recorded output should always make clear when it first went on air and should be identified as being pre-recorded. ' '

Blizzard, the US gaming giant, has shut down one of the largest fan-run servers for the original World of Warcraft (WWW), which is now 12 years old. World of Warcraft is an online multi-player game in which players explore a vast landscape, complete quests and interact with other gamers. The original game from 2004 has since been updated with new instalments that some players say materially changed the experience of the game, so some fans have set up their own servers to play the original, "vanilla" WW, a version of the game known as the "classic" WW. The 2011 blog post announcing an update to WW was met with anger from WW players, some of whom created a fan petition opposing the changes. In November 2013, the "Wow classic servers" petition attracted 100,000 signatures. The version of game that WW fans had been petitioning for was called WW: Legion and was launched in August 2016. There was almost universal relief in Japan on Friday as the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) gained a majority in both houses of parliament. The poll win puts an unpopular, lame-duck coalition government in the history books and has ensured that the LDP will take back the seats of power. The LDP was seen as the natural party of government after its near 50-year stranglehold on power was loosened by scandals and a slow economy, but it was still unpopular at the start of the election campaign. The BBC Asia editor Rupert Wingfield-Hayes says the LDP's victory is a major boost for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who is seen as a hawkish, right-of-centre leader who has led his party to an almost unbroken run of success in national elections, including eight general elections since 1955.

  He then instructed his trainees, who thought he was role playing, on what to do before he passed out.

  "I had just started my lecture and we were talking about cardiopulmonary resuscitation," Mr Knowles said.

  "The more senior members of the group had asked for a demonstration...she thought I was role playing, but I told her it was real and that I was going to lose consciousness."

  Mr Knowles, a St John Ambulance volunteer, went into cardiac arrest, but his trainees called 999 and gave him CPR until an ambulance crew arrived.

  "I'm told I came to, briefly, and was talking to the paramedics about my condition, but the next thing I remember is waking up in hospital, two and a half weeks later," he said.

At the height of the Cold War, former Labour cabinet minister Tony Benn was considered by the Soviet Union an 'unnecessary simpleton' who was too stupid to recruit as an agent, a KGB defector has claimed. Oleg Gordievsky, who was tasked with spying for the KGB while posted in London as a resident designate in the 1980s, warned his colleagues that if elected deputy-leader of the Labour party, Benn would ruin the Cold War political balance. Although tasked with running a Soviet intelligence operation from London, Mr Gordievsky had in fact worked for MI6 since 1974. Scroll down for video . Soviet defector Oleg Gordievsky claims the Russians considered Benn too 'simple' to recruit . This led to him being named a Companion of the Most Distinguished Order in the 2007 Queen's Birthday Honours for his assistance to British national security. But in an interview with The Telegraph, Mr Gordievsky has now claimed Benn was ignored by Soviet diplomats as a potential source because he was unreliable and made false claims. In the United Kingdom in 2019, thousands of 17-year-old pupils were unable to pass their A-level science exams after facing a paper that didn't reflect their course material. They are now attempting to get another chance to re-take the exam.
The Queen Mary's College in Basingstoke reported that a repeat exam paper was supplied instead of the anticipated content.
The college has received more than 4,000 signatures in support of a petition calling for an investigation.
The petition was created by two A level students, Annabel Smith, who plans on becoming a vet, and Alexandra Elkins, who wants to study dentistry.
Alexandra Elkins and Annabel were expected to receive top-grade A levels. Their school contacted Ofqual, Pearson and Edexcel and a paper re-take is being suggested. The two girls who created the petition, have expressed the desire for a re-sitting in December, before Christmas, and a re-write, with new questions, so everybody can be equally assessed.

Article: Alexandra Elkins and Annabel Smith, who are studying at Queen Mary's College, Basingstoke, now want to re-sit the exam with a new series of questions.
More than 4,000 people from across the country have signed a protest petition.
The Pearson group which provides the Edexcel exams said its papers "accurately reflect the curriculum".
Alexandra Elkins said: "I turned over the first paper and I looked at what was written and I thought, 'this can't be right, this isn't the right paper'."
Annabel Smith said: "I flicked through the rest of the paper after reading the first question thinking, 'okay maybe this is just one question and the rest of it will get onto the stuff that we know'," she said.
However, she added all the questions were "off-topic".
They say the paper was a repeat of a previous paper for AS Level students two years ago, covering topics which they were not taught.
Those who have signed the online petition have also labelled the paper as "ridiculous" and "unacceptable".

"As part of the UK’s Qualifications Reform Programme, we are developing reformed qualifications in collaboration with Ofqual and exam boards. Under our reformed 9 to 1 system, grade 1 in English will represent the equivalent performance of a C in the current national curriculum, and so on. Under this new system, Edexcel GCSEs in 2016/2017 will be the last opportunity for all learners of English to gain a final A* grade.
The current grades will also be available in all other Edexcel GCSEs in 2016/2017, alongside the new grades. The full reformed GCSEs (9-1) in all subjects will be available for first teaching in September 2016 with 9-1 first exams scheduled in June 2017, which marks us moving to a single examination window for these subjects.
In response to requests from teachers, we will also be offering English/mathematics and science foundation tier only papers to cater for the needs of learners not meeting progression entry requirements."

Education has a dramatic impact on children’s health later in life and, thus, society.
  Yet in many countries, more than 60% of children have never been taught that daily, healthy practices like bathing or brushing their teeth can prevent them from getting sick. This has far-reaching consequences for health, productivity, and economic growth.
  The Global Youth Coalition for Health is calling on the United Nations to act on four resolutions that, taken together, could transform millions of children’s lives. These resolutions call for the creation of a global public health campaign on health-promoting behaviours, a global monitoring system on child health, a Global Commission on Young People’s Health, and a global public-private partnership to support governments in implementing programmes to improve child health.
  With support from World Economic Forum’s Global Agenda Council on Universal Health Coverage, the Global Youth Coalition for Health has brought together 42 organizations, including the World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF. The goal is to get governments to incorporate these resolutions into this month’s UN General Assembly, where member states will consider a “political declaration” on universal health coverage to accelerate

Moldovan lives under steep slopes prone to landslides - so the locals call them "People of the Ravines". "Of course we're scared whenever the earth comes down", said Moldovan, as a hissing noise accompanied a minor shower of sand and clay. "But what can we do? The local authorities aren't interested in giving us any help," he complained. Across the road lives Petruta Paraschiva Otvos. When I visited 10 years ago she told me how she had been buried alive in a landslide in her backyard, then dug out by her neighbours and taken to hospital. Since then she has done menial jobs in Spain, together with her four children, and they managed to build this new home, with four rooms for four families. She is proud to have a two-storey house, but told me they often skipped meals, too, to save money.

Office for National Statistics figures released on Wednesday.

There are now 88,000 people unemployed and looking for work - 5.9% of the working age population, according to Office for National Statistics figures released on Wednesday.

But the unemployment rate in Wales is still higher than the UK rate of 5.2%.

Although unemployment is down, the employment level has also fallen and there is a rise in economic inactivity.

This includes people who are not working or classed as unemployed, for example studying or caring for a family member.

The Welsh government said over the past year, Wales had "outperformed almost every other part of the UK", recording the joint largest fall in the unemployment rate and the second largest increase in the rate of employment.

Welsh Secretary Stephen Crabb said the "fruits of Welsh economic recovery" were evident across the country.

But he added the mixed figures show "there is absolutely no room for complacency" and the recovery was "fragile"..

Article: By .

Ted Thornhill .

PUBLISHED: . 16:28 EST, 27 March 2012 . | . UPDATED: . 16:28 EST, 27 March 2012 . Shock waves from comets bombarding the Earth may have helped to build proteins and set the stage for life, scientists have learned[1].

Comets, giant snowballs of ice and dust, are known to have carried organic chemicals and water to the early Earth[2].

But just what caused life to spring out of nowhere on a barren and desolate planet billions of years ago remains a mystery[3][4].

Rock on: It's thought that comets were responsible for kick-starting life on Earth

Now scientists may have part of the answer[5][6][7].

Laboratory experiments have shown that amino acids - organic molecules that are the building blocks of proteins - would have survived violent comet impacts[8].

What is more, the shock of a large comet impact would have provided the energy needed

A team of scientists recently found that the organic molecules which are the building blocks of life can survive impacts by large meteors and comets, providing the energy and the water needed to start bonding amino acids together and creating proteins. Proteins provide the raw material that allows all living things, from microbes to humans, to exist and function. Their creation by comets may explain how life appeared so quickly at the end of a period 3.8 billion years ago called the ‘late heavy bombardment’. Dr Jennifer Blank, who led the U.S. scientists from the Nasa/Ames Research Centre in Moffett Field, California, said: ‘Our research shows that the building blocks of life could, indeed, have remained intact despite the tremendous shock wave and other violent conditions in a comet impact. ‘Comets really would have been the ideal packages for delivering ingredients for the chemical evolution thought to have resulted in life. We like the comet delivery scenario because it includes all of the ingredients for life - amino acids, water and energy.’ Dr Blank described the experiments at the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society in San Diego, California. https://phys.org/news/2012

Comet strikes on early earth could have jump-started life ``` For more information, on the topic, [see full article by Ted Thornhill, March 27, 2012, “[Shock waves from comets bombarding] Earth may have helped to build proteins and set the stage for life”]( https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2123152/Shock-waves-comets-bombarding-Earth-helped-build-proteins-stage-life.html ); or [read the article online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2123152/Shock-waves-comets-bombarding-Earth-helped-build-proteins-stage-life.html), for additional content. ``` For full article, see :  Ted Thornhill, " Shock waves from comets bombarding the Earth may have helped to build proteins and set the stage for life ," Daily Mail, accessed, Mar, 27, 2012, https

Amino acids, the building blocks of proteins, could survive large comet impacts, researchers are claiming. They said this showed how life could have began on Earth. Nasa had found signs of the impact of comets around 3.8 billion years ago. They believed this created proteins as a result of the impact. But they weren't sure if those amino acids would survive the aftermath. Research was able to simulate a comet impact by firing a projectile into a box full of silicon carbide - a solid like sand. They could then monitor the amino acids present in the box - by using a technique called vibrational spectroscopy - for two weeks before and after the impact to see whether it damaged them. The data showed that the amino acids survived the impacts but were transformed into other forms. So they concluded that a comet impact was likely to be the cause of proteins on Earth.```

The latest installment in the global scramble for economic influence in Asia was played out Friday in Tokyo, where a Chinese delegation led by Vice President Li Yuanchao met, in a friendly fashion, with new prime minister Shinzo Abe, who was elected on a campaign to reverse Japan's downward political and economic spiral.

China's recent diplomatic charm offensive in Asia is aimed at extending the economic and political influence Beijing already enjoys in the region and strengthening its influence against that of the United States. It should be noted that as part of his economic diplomacy campaign in the region, Li, who is the fourth ranking member of China's government, met earlier in the week with the prime ministers of Pakistan and Mongolia.

Mr. Abe, a conservative nationalist and unabashed admirer of the economic model of Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan, who returned to the prime minister's office this week after first holding the post in 2006, is a strong supporter of the United States. He appears to welcome a greater American profile in Asia, not as a counter to China's rise but as an enabler. In his 30

Prime Minister Shinzo Abe offered the world a vision of his country as a reinvigorated Asian power, pledging to restore its influence in a region where it is increasingly eclipsed by China, with his declaration that "Japan is back." China on Friday criticised Mr Abe after the Washington Post published an interview quoting him as saying Beijing had a "deeply ingrained" need to challenge its neighbours over territory. Japanese officials said the quote was "misleading" and Mr Abe had not said China sought conflicts with other countries. Mr Abe came to Washington seeking to erase a perceived ambivalence about Japan's relations with the US that was created by the previous centre-left government, which Mr Abe's Liberal Democratic party defeated in national elections in December. Japan has swapped prime ministers six times since Mr Abe first held the office in a short.

2011
  Vince Cable
  The Business Department
  The Department

  This is the story of the biggest case of British corporate criminal negligence of our time, and how the guilty ones got away with it: HBoS was the biggest British bank failure, and Andy Hornby was the chief executive who presided over its demise. But for reasons the British public may never understand, and which go into its DNA, he got away with it. Hornby and his two ex-chiefs, Sir James Crosby and Lord Stevenson, were not even referred to the Serious Fraud Office to begin a criminal prosecution, although the case for that was made. Even an official enquiry that spanned three years and cost £26 million has not called for their head. I think this has been a systemic failure and has revealed the weakness of one of most important institutions. The UK is seen as a beacon of probity and transparency in the world, and for good reason. But when it comes to corporate criminal negligence, and when the banksters have friends in high places, the system just hasn't worked.

  Vince Cable wants to see

In a world of increasing complexity, our financial system must ensure the efficient allocation of ever-dwindling resources to their most effective and ethical uses. This requires a healthy, honest, transparent and trusted financial system, one that serves the needs of businesses, investors and consumers alike. At the same time this system must be robust enough that its failure will not inflict catastrophic damage on our economies.   When the financial system is operating correctly, it performs many essential functions in a modern society and is a vital tool for improving the prosperity of its citizens. This is possible because of the essential roles it plays in allocating, measuring and monitoring the distribution of capital, risk and information.   But when it is not operating correctly, the financial system performs a wholly different role: it impoverishes those on fixed incomes, including the elderly; it wastes capital that could have been invested in new jobs or productive infrastructure; and it diverts economic opportunity to groups such as the corrupt and organised criminals who manipulate the system for self-enrichment or for their own purposes.   In the worst of cases, it can also subvert or destroy the moral fabric of a wider society, as has been seen in recent years; these

From samba and carnival to food, music and religion, African culture is everywhere in Brazil. The cultural heritage stems from the estimated four million slaves who were brought to the country over a 300-year period, at least four times as many as to the United States. Brazil was the last country to abolish the slave trade in 1888. More than half of Brazilians now identify themselves as black or of mixed race, according to the latest census. Rio de Janeiro now has the most famous carnival in the world, attracting an estimated 1.1 million visitors to the city this year and with 5.3 million people taking part in street parties, according to the English language newspaper The Rio Times. Carnival, which is celebrated across Brazil, combines samba -- music and dance which grew out of Brazil's black neighborhoods -- and the Catholic tradition of celebrating the run-up to Lent brought by Portuguese colonialists. After the abolition of slavery, the rituals of the Catholic former colonialists and their former slaves merged to form the origins of modern carnival, according to the Rio Times. `````` I have long believed that Giving Credit When Due is vital to being a successful person, but also to not have a hard time when things go wrong. After all, many are quick to blame others for one's failure, but seldom give credit when things go right. And how can one expect positive changes to be made without giving credit where credit is due? It's vital to understand and be able to communicate how things can be done better, or what the reason is for things going right. ````````` The full, original post in HTML can be read at http://blog.japher.com/2014/08/17/giving-credit-when-due.html and the discussion has already moved to my website: blog.japher.com Thanks for reading.

  Mr Peake arrived at the ISS on 15 December in a Soyuz spacecraft to begin a six-month mission aboard the orbiting outpost.

Dear fellow humans, it is difficult to make a coherent argument over twitter. But, here is my best shot:

1) Progress M-28M is indeed a new Progress. I wrote the story with that in mind. It's an upgrade over its previous model. I could have added some of the features in the story, but would have turned it into a listicle.
There was more to it than that - such as what it was carrying.
2) Yes, Roscosmos has made improvements. They have had to since the last Progress vehicle made a spectacular collision with MIR. No-one has died in that incident, though.
3) It was launched in Kazakhstan and will likely reach Eagle Base, an old launch site just 50miles from Baikonor and a very good place from where I watched the launch of Soyuz TMA-16M.
4) The Progress vehicle did indeed arrive at the orbiting outpost. It was a 2-days trip from Earth to the ISS. One cannot really call it "the longest space journey in history". The longest journey was back in 2000, to Mars. But that is

## MUI partners with General Motors to build shipping container house

Detroit, Michigan - They may not look like the most spacious, or glamorous, of buildings. But these shipping containers have been earmarked as a novel way to tackle the housing crisis in Detroit, Michigan.

In one of the city's sprawling factories, the first converted shipping container is being constructed and it is hoped it might potentially be a model for the future.

The first shipping container converted home is being constructed in a Detroit General Motors factory . It is hoped the shipping container idea could take off and be used as a way to tackle the city's housing crisis . Once the finishing touches have been applied, the container will be delivered to Michigan Urban Farming Initiative's headquarters in Detroit's North End neighborhood. It will serve as a base for university student caretakers for the nonprofit group and agricultural research activities.

Up to this point, the Indian rupee has been denoted by "Rs" or the abbreviation INR. The new symbol, which looks like an R in Hindi, with an intersecting horizontal line, was selected after a public contest involving 3,000 designs, Ambika Soni, India's information and broadcasting minister, said. India approved a distinct symbol for its currency, the rupee, Thursday, joining the league of currencies identifiable by their unique signs. Up to this point, the Indian rupee has been denoted by "Rs" or the abbreviation INR. The new symbol, which looks like an R in Hindi, with an intersecting horizontal line, was selected after a public contest involving 3,000 designs, Ambika Soni, India's information and broadcasting minister, said. The move to give to its currency a new recognition stems from the country's economic growth, the minister said. "The symbol for the rupee would lend a distinctive character and identity to the currency and further highlight the strength and robustness of the Indian economy as also a favored destination for global investments," Soni said. She also noted that the symbol would help distinguish the Indian rupee from the namesake currencies of several other nations like Pakistan, Nepal and Sri Lanka. Apart from citing her country's rapid integration with the global economy as a reason for adopting a symbol for the Indian rupee, Soni also noted the cultural importance to the new currency, because

This game was won in dramatic fashion thanks to a touchdown pass in the overtime, where the Seahawks were able to defeat the Packers. The Seahawks entered this game as underdogs given the amazing season the Packers had, defeating the top scorer in the NFL, Aaron Rodgers. The Seahawks were down for most of the game, and it looked as if they would not make the next Superbowl, after they had made it last year. However, in the last quarter and in overtime, the Seahawks were able to capitalized on the Packers mistakes. This win made it the fourth final game the Seahawks have ever played at home, with the previous three being Super Bowl appearances. Seattle's record is 4-0 for championship games that they have played at home, with the last two of these four being Superbowl appearances. The Seahawks are now going to the Superbowl for the second year in a row, and it will be played in Phoenix, Arizona on Sunday February 1, 2015. ```

## Seattle Seahawks fire a come-from-behind Hail Mary to win the NFC Championship at the Green Bay Packers

   The Seattle Seahawks, bidding to become the first team in a decade to win back-to-back Super Bowls, will now play the New England Patriots after they hammered the Indianapolis Colts. Trailing 19-7 the Seahawks scored 15 points in 44 seconds late in the fourth quarter - Wilson and Marshawn Lynch each powering their way into the end zone for touchdowns and adding a two-point conversion to surge ahead 22-19. VIDEO Seattle Seahawks wide receiver Jermaine Kearse (left) celebrates with tight end Luke Willson after catching the  winning touchdown pass against the Green Bay Packers during the overtime period in the NFC Championship game at CenturyLink Field . Kearse throws the ball into the stands after scoring the game-winning touchdown against the Green Bay Packers . Willson celebrates with wide receiver Kearse  after catching a pass for a two-point conversion score against Green Bay Packers free safety Ha Ha Clinton-

Russell Wilson hit Jermaine Kearse with a 35-yard touchdown pass in overtime , putting Seattle Seahawks past  Green Bay Packers (28-22) and on to Super Bowl appearance. In what had been a funeral atmosphere much of the game as the Seahawks looked headed to an end of their reign , with the score just 12-19 coming into the last six minutes, Wilson , who had misfired most of the day, flashed champion pedigree with a 35-yard touchdown pass to Jermaine Kearse  to put Seattle in front with less than two minutes left. At that point, Seattle had scored 15 points in 44 seconds , but they still had 35 seconds left to the Green Bay with the home crowd going into overtime stunned. The drama was far from over , as the Packers' Mason Crosby booted his fifth field goal of the day to send the game into OT. The contest had been billed as one of the best matchups this season, and certainly lived up to that hype, with some clutch plays from two champions that will meet each other again in Super Bowl XLIX

1. Britain,

Suez Crisis Background Winston Churchill had sent in troops to seize the canal in 1956, when Egypt nationalized the Suez canal. He did this, he said, to prevent the Soviets from "playing the Egyptian card". The American reaction was quick and unambiguous: "We condemn any aggressive and unauthorised intervention by our allies into the affairs of a sovereign state." They suspended arms supplies to France and Britain as a result. The French President took Britain aside and told them that if they did not give in to the US and pull out then they would be "unworthy of our friendship" This time the American response was muted - but they made it clear that they would not provide any help. The war was halted within five days as the Soviets threatened to intervene on Egypt's behalf. It was an extraordinary outcome: the two big colonial powers had been brought to their knees by the USA and one of their former colonies. Implications The Suez crisis was the biggest diplomatic embarrassment in British history. But it did at least provide an opportunity: for a change in the way that Britain saw the world - in more than fifty years Britain had lost just about every territory it once

Britain and America were at each other's side for the duration of the Second World War, but in the decades that followed, things became more complicated. The US had become the 'indispensable nation'.  Washington had been frustrated at the British - and their European allies - attempts to undermine the emerging rapprochement between France and Germany. There’s a new paper in the field of computational social science that is attracting all sorts of attention: “Social Structure as a Cause of the Great Depression.” That’s great. The research is of sufficient quality that it has sparked an intense dialogue around how best to think about the role of social networks in explaining economic outcomes. While the paper is highly empirical, with a new approach to measuring network structure with a detailed micro data set (from a 1937 survey of American farmers called the 17), and with some sophisticated econometric technique, the paper is also quite conceptual and theoretical. So, it’s a great model (and a great discussion). But, as a friend told me, if you want to write a paper in this area – which is my research area as well as my academic and personal interests – you are essentially required to read this paper. So the idea of the post is to take a look at this very brief summary of their work. Because that’s actually what I did as part of my research.

A 19th-century Italian opera about a love triangle between a young soprano singer,, Mary Austin Green () and her two suitors,, Charles Calthorpe () and Sir Arthur, a knight, is well known and still performed. In an effort to get Calthorpe to choose her, Austin Green tricks Sir Arthur () into having a dinner party with her and Calthorpe, and has Sir Arthur sing the song "La Donna e Mobile" (The Woman Is Fickle). As Sir Arthur sings the song, Calthorpe becomes jealous of it. When Calthorpe sees Austin Green later, he realises that the singer was not the young woman, and that Sir Arthur has had a previous love affair with Austin Green's mother. Calthorpe becomes even more enraged when he learns that Sir Arthur is leaving town, as part of the Queen of's () entourage, and Calthorpe has learned that no man can live without love. This was a legal case in which a member of Northern Irish devolved legislature (and a failed candidate in the recent election) Phil Flanagan sued the firm Amlin Insurance (part of AIG), under the policy that parliamentary members are required to take out through MLAs in NI. He sued them for refusing to cover him under his insurance because his tweet had the potential to be defamatory. Phil Flanagan posted some tweets that implied that Tom Elliott (a former Unionist Party MLA who also did a bit of soldiering) had shot or harassed people. That is false. The judge found that tweets defamatory, requiring an apology and the payment of some compensation, and the court ordered a stay on paying any damages until Flanagan's insurance case had concluded. In defending from suit by Flanagan, the lawyers for Amlin argued that the terms of the insurance require that they do not insure Flanagan because he knew that what he tweeted about Tom Elliott was defamatory and thus his tweets were not covered. The judge has allowed this defence, and has awarded AIG their costs and legal fees because this has been such a point

Deposit return scheme for drinks containers supported by drinks giant
Coca-Cola has announced it will support the "sensible introduction" of a deposit return scheme for drinks containers.
Such an initiative has been backed by environmental groups, who say it could massively improve recycling rates and tackle litter
A deposit return scheme (DRS) allows customers to return empty cans and bottles to the retailer, who pay a deposit which is then refunded when the product is returned for recycling.
The association for protection of rural Scotland has long been campaigning for such an approach to tackle the problem of bottle and packaging disposal.
A report by Zero Waste Scotland found that in Wales, such schemes had raised recycling rates by more than 30 % .
APRS chief executive Stuart Hay said "The bottle crisis has rumbled on under our noses for too long. With so many of them littering our parks and beaches, we hope that the Scottish Government will listen to the companies that make the most money from producing and selling drinks, and heed the science that tells us that a deposit scheme can reduce the amount of drinks litter that gets left behind."

Coca-Cola is now considering a deposit scheme to tackle the 3.2 billion cans and 1.3 billion bottles that make up Coca-Cola Scotland's sales each year, a spokesman said.

Scottish Environment Secreatary Richard Lochhead said that Coca-Cola's backing is a "significant development".
He added that the firm had made "significant progress" in recent years towards making its packaging more sustainable, and was now looking at "ways we can collaborate with others to improve recycling rates and reduce litter".
The Marine Conservation Society said it was "great to see Coca-Cola recognise the advantages" of such a scheme, while WWF Scotland said they "very much welcome" the move.

        Half the fun of Halloween is coming up with new, creative outfits that will blow your friends' minds and maybe scare a few impressionable children. (The other half, obviously, is candy.) Technology can help. Take, for example, that classic Halloween accessory, the realistic festering wound. Former NASA employee Mark Rober has created an app that shows animations of moving, oozing innards. Put your iOS or Android smartphone in a special fleshy case, add a carefully bloodied, ripped T-shirt and you have The iWound. There is also a moving eyeball outfit and a new effect that makes it look like a hand is ripping out your guts from behind. Rober first got the idea for mixing Halloween and smartphones in 2011

# Article : Three Michigan children reportedly left alone in their family's apartment died in a fire Monday afternoon, a public safety official said. The fire broke out around 2 p.m. in Kalamazoo, said Brian Uridge, assistant chief of public safety. Two of the children were 3 years old, and the third was 1, Uridge said.

Three Michigan children reportedly left alone in their family''s apartment died in a fire Monday afternoon, a public safety official said. The fire broke out around 2 p.m. in Kalamazoo, said Brian Uridge, assistant chief of public safety.

Two of the children were 3 years old, and the third was 1, Uridge said.

“You could see smoke from blocks away,” Uridge said. The main floor of the apartment building was engulfed in flames when firefighters arrived, and “they found three kids who had already perished as a result of the fire,” he said.

The cause of the fire is unknown, he said. The children's parents were at the scene, Uridge said. ``Initially, we have information that the kids were left alone in the apartment, but we can't talk about charges because it's too early in the investigation,'' Uridge said.

The victims' identities have not been released.````

The UK government has granted Cornwall a designation of "national minority," despite warnings of a public backlash. The designation comes with little more than an assurance that those of Cornish descent will be allowed to pass on their culture to their children.
The decision has been widely criticised as unnecessary and potentially insulting to Cornish people, in light of Cornwall's already-secure protections of their culture.
The announcement has been widely seen as a gesture to the Liberal Democrat members of the coalition government, with the designation being announced by a Lib Dem minister and appearing to satisfy one of Lib Dem leader Nick Clegg's stated desires.
As the two coalition parties continue to clash over policies, it is becoming increasingly clear that the Liberal Democrats are placing a high priority on maintaining a large degree of autonomy from conservatives. Although the Conservatives are also unhappy with the decision, they are reported to be generally powerless to prevent it due to their commitment to respect the opinions of the Liberal Democrats in the governing cabinet.'```

Note that there is an online version of this story at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cornish_people#Recognition_by_the_UK.

Cornish people have been given official minority status - but only in return for Government spending cuts.

Cornwall is officially recognised as a UK minority region by the Government, after Nick Clegg reached a deal with the Lib Dems on local government pensions reform on February 22.

The Cornish Heritage Bill has yet to be voted on. Critics say that it will increase pension costs for councils by about £1 billion - because more money will be spent on pensioners who have lived in the region for 20 years or more, but not for those who have moved in more recently.

"Recognising the unique historical features of Cornwall can only contribute to the distinctive character of Cornwall, that is so important to many who live here," Cornwall's Chief Cornish Officer Peter Smith-Hughes tells MailOnline.

The Cornish Heritage Bill had been due to be voted on by Parliament last week, giving official recognition to the Cornish as a national minority and guaranteeing the protection of Cornwall's cultural and environmental heritage.``` Note: This is not an automated text-to-html converstion. Sepsis kills over 37,000 people a year in the UK and is the result of bacteria leaking from an infection and travelling to the lungs or bloodstream, releasing toxins into the blood.

A team of researchers from US and UK Universities, led by Dr. James Carey, now hopes to have developed an effective and fast screening tool which can reduce infection-related sepsis.

The artificial nose system can now detect dangerous bacteria such as E.Coli and Streptococcus.

The system is made up of small plastic bottles filled with a mixture of glucose, amino acids and minerals that keep the bacteria alive. The system requires very little time and money to manufacture and could potentially be used to save lives around the world.``` 3

In 2020, the RSPCA had to abandon a campaign to criminalise hunting because of a ruling from the Supreme Court. Even without that, it seemed that public attitudes were in favour of retaining the right to hunt. The RSPCA should stop attempting to bring criminal prosecutions against hunts, an independent inquiry found yesterday. The charity should also rethink its longstanding role of taking animal cruelty cases to court, and help develop a new system in which it would work with Government agencies to bring offenders to book. "Today’s travel nightmare stories are in the past for Sandy Valdivieso and her husband, Triet Vo. The couple boarded a Turkish Airways flight in Los Angeles for a trip from LA to Dakar, Senegal in western Africa but they landed 7,000 miles away from their intended destination in Bangladesh."```

The headline is Ever gotten on a plane and wound up in the wrong city? How about the wrong continent? According to a Los Angeles Times report, that's the travel nightmare story Sandy Valdivieso and her husband, Triet Vo, will get to tell for the rest of their lives. The couple boarded a flight in Los Angeles booked by Turkish Airways, intending to travel to Dakar, Senegal, in western Africa. Instead, they got off the plane in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in South Asia, almost 7,000 miles away. The culprit was apparently a mix-up between the similarly pronounced cities and the three-letter code used by airlines to distinguish airports. The three-letter airport code on the tickets issued to the couple by the airline read DAC, the code for the airport in Dhaka. The code for the airport in Dakar is DKR. The couple simply assumed that DAC was the code for their airport. "Even after they'd settled into their seats, they did not realize that DAC was the airport code for Dhaka, Bangladesh, not Dakar, Senegal, he said. "The tickets never mention

For cities in the United States, the beginning of the three-letter code is the airport's two-letter code in the International Air Transport Association, IATA, system. Then comes "D" for domestic or "F" for foreign. Then the last letter of the destination city, which often is the same as the city's name. Example: The domestic airport for Kansas City, Mo., is MOW. Sandy Valdivieso and her husband, Triet Vo, were booked for a flight to Dakar, Senegal by Turkish Airlines. The couple assumed that the airport code DAC for their flight was the airport code for Dakar. They realized the mistake when they exited the flight, only to find they were in Dhaka, Bangladesh. They had to stay overnight there, at their own cost, before the airline could rebook them to Dakar 6 days later.```

It is difficult to understand why they take such a risky job, when there are so many alternatives . Laos had many people being maimed or killed by unexploded bombs from the American bombing campaigns during the Vietnam war. Thirty seven million bomblets or "bombies" were dropped on Laos during the years 1964-1973 with another six million dropped before then. The most bombing took place between 1964 and 1973 when the North Vietnamese were using the Planes of Jars area as a supply route and air defence system for the Ho Chi Minh Trail. The Ho Chi Minh Trail was over 700 miles of narrow mountain trails along the VietnamâLaos border through which the communist North brought weapons and supplies to the Vietnam People's Army. The US had bombed a trail and the Ho Chi Minh Trail and its supporting supply and staging areas that ran through Laos and Cambodia, to sever supply routes that the North Vietnamese were using. In reality, the Ho Chi Minh Trail was used by both sides of the war during the Vietnam conflict. By November 1972 the bombing was over and it is estimated that millions of bombs either did not explode or were duds

The United States has dropped 600,000 tonnes of bombs on Laos. This is equivalent to a plane load of bombs every eight minutes, 24-hours a day for nine years - making Laos the most bombed nation in history. But Forest looked far better. Our midfield actually looked a midfield for the first time in a good while, and our wide men on the right (Matt Mills) and the left (Ryan Mendes actually) put in some good performance. A man in his 50s was killed last night after being hit by an ambulance, Northumbria. Police said that the ambulance was transferring a patient between Berwick and Wansbeck in Northumberland. It was a non-emergency, so the vehicle wasn't travelling with sirens or blue lights. The crew were being supported by a senior ambulance officer and were described as being "extremely shocked". ''There were no injuries to the ambulance patient or crew, but we would urge any witnesses to the collision to contact the police to help with their investigation," he added. Tory transport spokesman Russell George accused the Welsh Government of "hypocrisy", given its view that Severn Bridge tolls should be abolished.
Referring to the Cleddau Bridge tolls at 75p for cars and £1.50 for lorries, he said: "They've done nothing to tackle the one toll it could scrap."
The Welsh Government said it was a local authority matter.
Pembrokeshire council decided in May to keep the tolls in place after a review.
The criticism comes after the UK government announced plans to cut the Severn Bridge tolls by more than half.
Cars, vans and small buses could pay as little as £3 from 2018, after the crossings return to public ownership.
Wales' Economy Secretary Ken Skates said the tolls should be scrapped, as a tax on entering Wales.
Mr George criticised the minister, claiming he failed to answer his point about the Cleddau Bridge when he raised the issue of tolls in the Senedd.

Many people get a new job and they also get a new laptop. Not every one has the same laptop (some might be better or worse). Mostly people use the same software on these laptops. The question about which software the users prefer is the main question for us. Many open source libraries are developed on a regular basis. If someone is asked to write a program, he needs to choose among the available open source libraries. Every open source library has some set of users. Most of them may be happy with the library, but some of them may not be happy with it. This depends on the quality of the library (that is, the quality of the code of the library). We want to find out if people, who are not happy with the library, are more likely to contribute to that library. We also want to find out if quality impacts the usage of the library. We want to know if a user contributes to an open source library if he is happy about it or whether he contributes, because he is not happy about it. We want to find out how often does the user change the library and which reason he has to change the library. BBC TOKYO AUCTION
Japanese auction fish buyer pushes record to $1.76 m
Sun Jan 9, 2011 9:03pm EST
TOKYO (Reuters) - A Japanese sushi restaurant chain owner paid $1.76 million for a large bluefin tuna at Tokyo's Tsukiji fish market, smashing the previous record by nearly $1 million in his third consecutive bidding triumph at the annual sales spree.
Kiyoshi Kimura, who runs over 40 Sushi Zanmai outlets, made the winning bid of 155.4 million yen ($1.76 million) for a 222-kg (486-pound) tuna at the opening auction at Tsukiji early on Monday morning.
The previous record was set at the same auction by Kimura at $882,000 in 2010 and his top price in 2009 was $733,000, a spokesman for the fish market said.
"This is the first auction of the year,"

(The) Article: High bids traditionally mark the year's first auction at Tokyo's Tsukiji fish market. Even the buyer, sushi chain owner Kiyoshi Kimura, who also paid out the record price last year, said the cost was "a bit high".'' The sale came amid continued warnings from environmentalists that tuna stocks are dwindling and overfished. This year's record-breaking fish was caught off north-eastern Japan and weighed in at 222kg (489lbs), some 47kg lighter than last year's prize-winner, which fetched 56m yen. The prices do not necessarily reflect quality or size and are more linked to publicity and setting the tone for the business year. The auction at the market - which trades millions of dollars of products daily and is a popular tourist destination -  began at 05:00 local time. The revelation follows figures released in September showing that 6,580 under-18s – and 293 children aged 11 and under – were admitted to A&E for alcohol-related admissions. Meanwhile, it was reported in The Sun today that cases of foetal alcohol syndrome - where babies are left deformed or disabled by their mother's drinking during pregnancy - rose by 48 per cent between 2009-10 and 2012. Last year, doctors saw 313 cases of foetal alcohol syndrome, up from just 211 in the previous year alone. And the most staggering claim is that up to 2,000 British newborns a year could have physical and mental disabilities, learning difficulty and problems with behaviour because their mothers consumed alcohol during pregnancy, which is linked to an up to 20% risk of their child developing fetal alcohol syndrome. Last year the NHS estimated 9,000 under-18s each year were admitted to hospital for alcohol-related admissions and today the UK's public health minister Jane Ellison blamed the "normalisation of drinking”. William Paterson is alleged to have repeatedly shot and killed 29-year-old Mr Carroll outside Asda, in the city's Robroyston area, on 13 January 2010. He is also accused of fleeing to Spain 10 days later "to avoid arrest, prosecution and conviction". The trial is taking place at the High Court in Glasgow. An excerpt from a telephone call made by Mr Paterson to his girlfriend Sarah Maguire from prison in October last year was played to the court. In it he was heard telling her that he had been served with his indictment and that there were 350 witnesses on the list, including her father. Giving evidence to the jury, Miss Maguire's father Kevin Maguire, 70, told the court that Mr Paterson was in a relationship with his daughter and before going to Spain in January 2010 sometimes stayed at their house. Det Sgt Grant Durie, who searched the house where Miss Maguire lived with her father in Cumbernauld, also gave evidence. He told the court he was the crime scene manager and that during the search a bulletproof vest was found under

29-year-old William Paterson is charged with the murder of his brother-in-law Kevin Carroll at a petrol station in Glasgow’s Robroyston area in January 2010. Paterson's lawyers have lodged a special defence of "incrimination", relating to witness accounts.

Warner said the stances taken by athletics' governing body, the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF), and the International Paralympic Committee (IPC) could be seen as a "turning point".
Russians have been banned by the IAAF from competing since November 2015, while the IPC banned Russia from taking part in the 2016 Rio Paralympics.
The International Olympic Committee (IOC) left decisions on whether Russians could compete at the Rio Olympics to individual sporting federations.
"There remains too much denial in too many quarters, but we will continue to work to make progress in the areas we can."
Last year, Warner said it was time for "radical reform".
Among UK Athletics' (UKA) proposals were plans to reset world records, introduce longer bans for drug cheats and a public register of tested athletes.

Richard R. McLaren was appointed by the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) to Chair an Independent Commission (Commission) to assist WADA in investigating whether there has been an "Institutional Conspiracy” in the Russian Anti-Doping Agency (RUSADA) involving the "manipulation” of athletes’ test results in the context of the Moscow Laboratory, to avoid detection and punishment of athletes for doping. The Commission’s mandate was not to determine whether any individual athlete was guilty of doping or to determine whether any coaches or medical staff acted inappropriately; instead, the investigation concentrated on the apparent systemic failures in the anti-doping system for both samples taken at the 2014 Sochi Winter Games and post-Sochi samples obtained by RUSADA and processed at the Moscow Laboratory. The final report of the Commission sets out, in detail, the findings that have been reached based on the evidence uncovered to date.

The Venezuelan government has called on public servants to work reduced hours and private companies to cut down on their air conditioning, as the country is gripped by the second day of a two-day nationwide electricity rationing plan. Vice-President Jorge Arreaza said there had been a surge in energy demand due to extremely hot weather. He said state employees would now work from 07:30-13:00 to save on air conditioning. On Monday, local media reported blackouts across the country. Mr Arreaza said private companies would be asked to use their own generators to reduce pressure on the national grid. But he said it was private homeowners who consumed the most energy, and he called for everyone to turn the dial down on their air conditioners. "We are appealing to everyone's conscience, to use energy efficiently." Last week the government claimed that energy problems were due to maintenance issues, but the opposition criticised the government for not investing enough in the energy sector, BBC Venezuela correspondent Daniel Pardo reports. {biz} In Venezuela, blackouts, record-breaking heat, and energy rationing have forced state workers to take a siesta in an attempt to reduce the country’s electricity consumption. The blackouts are a result of several of the country’s hydroelectric dams running at low water levels due to prolonged drought, says the country’s Vice President. As a result of increasing temperatures, energy demand rises, forcing the country to ration electricity. Since last week, citizens are asked to limit their electricity use between 16:00 and 18:00 and from 22:00 to 06:00. This means that government offices close down during these hours, and some workers work from home or rest at home. Since the blackouts began, many businesses are suffering because they are closed during the hottest hours. Temperatures of 45°C (113°F) or higher are recorded in the state of Apure, 45km south of the Equator. Fox is a WWII bombing mascot. He was a mascot for a Lancaster crew from RAF Metheringham, in Lincolnshire, from 1944 until the end of the war. He now goes unaccounted for. He is also well traveled. He went on 36 bomb missions, including one the night before D-Day 1944. He has had only one owner since then - a woman, named Rosemary Wilson. The Fox is on temporary loan to RAF Metheringham Visitor Centre, but he's absent without leave. The Fox is made from brown-and-white striped cloth. His wings are brown with white trim. His hat is red with a brown band. He's wearing khaki trousers tucked into red gaiters. He has a blue scarf and a red neckerchief on his neck. He has an RAF blue uniform on that says, "RAF Metheringham Airfield." He's also known to have two names - 'Mr Fox' and 'The Fox.' RAF Metheringham lost 59 Lancaster bombers and 300 aircrew during the war. R

Staff at Metheringham Airfield Visitor Centre said the stuffed toy was loaned out last year, but was never returned. Mr Fox is described as wearing a red coat and jodhpurs, and has details of some of the missions he was on written on his leg. The mascot was on more than 30 bombing raids with 106 Squadron, including one the night before D-Day. Visitor centre chairman Andy Marson said the mascot, which belonged to Flt Sgt Bill Hovey, a navigator with the squadron, was a very important part of the airfield's history, He said: "From March 1944 to August 1944 - Flt Sgt Hovey completed some 36 operations - which is quite something - so obviously Mr Fox was quite lucky for him. "Mr Fox is the one surviving crew member from all those operations, and has gone absent without leave, and obviously we want him back." The Argentine Dictatorship: An In-Depth Analysis

The Argentine Dictatorship, or "Proceso", lasted from 1976 to 1983 and marks a dark period in the country's history. During this time, state repression and human rights violations were widespread, resulting in the disappearance of an estimated 30,000 people.

The Proceso was led by a junta of military leaders, who seized power in a coup d'état in 1976. They maintained control of the government until democracy was restored in 1983. During the dictatorship, the military took a hardline approach to political dissent, carrying out extrajudicial killings, torture, and disappearances of left-wing activists, trade unionists, and other political opponents.

One of the worst examples of human rights abuses during the Argentine Dictatorship was the clandestine detention center known as "El Vesubio." Article: A two-year study of 92 different countries found that people living in regions with greater income inequality were less trustworthy than those living in less unequal countries, according to a study in Psychological Science.
Across the world, wealthy people often view less wealthy people with suspicion and resentment. This feeling is called "structural anger" and may be driving inequality up.
Structural anger is associated with higher levels of greed, resentment and discrimination among high-income earners, says lead researcher Sam Sommers, assistant professor of social psychology at Tufts University. People with this mindset have more negative feelings about others. When these negative feelings are directed towards the less wealthy, they may vote for politicians and laws that support policies to protect the wealthy, he says.
Sommers and his co-author asked an international sample of participants to predict what would happen to an individual after losing their job in a local factory. The Scottish Government has published statistics on homelessness numbers. The chief statistician said there had been a 4% reduction in homelessness applications compared to the previous year. However, there was a rise in the number of children in temporary accommodation.
The Scottish government said it wanted to work to reduce homelessness even further. The Homelessness and Housing Options Statistics report found there were 28,000 cases in Scotland assessed as homeless or threatened with homelessness.Of these, 25,000 cases were judged to be "unintentionally homeless" and therefore with a right to settled accommodation. About two-thirds secured this accommodation, mainly through the social or private rented sector.
Scottish local authorities said they received about 35,000 homelessness applications during 2015/16. There has been no change in the number of households in temporary accommodation.

Queen Elizabeth II unveils an 800kg bronze statue of two horses drawing her carriage. Horses have been used to draw the carriages of the British monarch for over a century. Today the Queen, Prince Philip and Prince William gathered to unveil a bronze statue of two horses drawing the carriage of the longest reigning UK monarch. Made from bronze, the almost 2-metre tall statue was created by sculptor Robert Rattray and cost about $250,000. The money to finance its creation came from residents of Windsor with a further portion of the funds raised from the Queen and the Duke of Edinborough's charitable trusts. Since the Queen came to the throne in 1952, she's had various horses drawn her carriages throughout her reign at events such as Trooping the Colour and Royal Ascot. The statue was unveiled to celebrate her long reign. The Regent Superbowl fire in Yarmouth was in a huge 4-storey complex, and despite many large and powerful appliances, and an aerial ladder used to direct water onto the fire, from 11.45 pm to 6.30 am it took hours and hours to bring the blaze under control. The detailed report says that, despite the complex water flow system installed, one of the aerial watertowers failed while fighting the fire. The firefighting operations had to adapt, and the fire was brought under control by 7.00 am. The Superbowl was a modern complex which had won many national awards for excellence in operation and construction. Its size was large, and despite many fire fighting appliance pumps and water towers, and firefighting operations taking place over several hours, the fire did considerable damage. We may learn much about what went wrong, and how operations might have been improved and lessons learnt. It is too early to give an opinion, but it would seem that the complexity of the firefighting operation was the main issue, as were the water towers, or lack of them in certain places.

---> The opening of a new entrance honoring former first lady and New York socialite Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis was celebrated in the Big Apple on Monday.

Onassis was part of a successful campaign to save Grand Central Terminal from demolition

Former First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis will forever have a presence at Grand Central Terminal in New York City following the opening of an entrance named in her honor on Monday. The entrance at Park Avenue and East 42nd Street is a tribute to Kennedy’s important role in fighting to save the station in the 1970s when plans were at an advanced stage to build a 53-story tower built atop the iconic structure. The newly renovated entrance has being named the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Foyer and features a large plaque bronze relief of Onassis and a description of her role in saving the terminal. Jackie Onassis, pictured in 1977, stands beside a huge photo of Grand Central Station during a news conference by the Committee To Save Grand Central, to plead that the terminal be spared demolition. summary : What you see here is two very different images of Jackie Kennedy that appeared on the cover of two separate issues of Life, a magazine that had been very enthusiastic about JFK but lost interest in Camelot after his death. The images represent two things. The first is a portrait of Jackie as a lady of the social and political elite with a special place in JFK's inner circle. The second is that same lady in a very casual moment, a lady who, as wife of one of the most powerful men in the world, has few reasons to smile and still manages to. I can't decide which I like best. As a photographer I really admire the first one for its composition, how it plays with the lines and contrasts. In the second one I find the composition a bit busy and I have a feeling it's more a reflection of what the magazine wanted at the time (a couple days after his assassination) than any actual portrait of Jackie. So I would definitely choose the first one. But I like the second one more, because it really does capture a smile you won't find anywhere else. I like both of them a lot.

In the Middle Ages, wealthy European cities with courts employed professional musicians, creating a demand for music; the craftsmanship that developed was respected and led in 16th Century Cremona to the invention of the violin.
In the 17th Century came the invention of the cello, by Giovanni Agostino Guarneri, a friend and pupil of Amati. Guarneri was the first to make his violins famous. In 1865 The New York Times published a feature extolling his virtues. He was " a true poet of sound ".
In 1849 The Prince Regent of Piedmont commissioned a violin from an up - and - coming member of the Guarneri dynasty, the 22 - year - old Giuseppe Giovanni Battista Guarneri del Gesu.
The Prince never heard it and died, but a story was handed down that the price of the instrument was 43 gold ducats for the violin and three for the case. Del Gesù was called so for the resemblance he showed in his work to the church of San Giovanni in Cremona, known as Gesu.
