The Prime Minister has called for parliament to debate voting at 16 after an internal poll found the 50% of Conservative supporters support extending the electoral franchise for the first time. According to the Prime Minister, the decision on whether or not to move to a 16-year-old electoral franchise is one for Parliament to decide. In the 2014 Scottish independence referendum, 18 to 24-year-olds voted 1.8%, twice that of over-75s. Labour's acting leader Harriet Harman has stated that the vote should be held after debate in Parliament. The current franchise consists of UK citizens over the age of 18 who are registered to vote, and those temporarily abroad (military members and other) are eligible to vote. The Prime Minister believes that extending the electoral franchise will help in the long-running argument against student votes being allowed in local elections. This would help to boost local government party support. This decision may not be made until a review of all the evidence is complete. The EU referendum date is likely to take place during June 2016.

Background:  A leading cause of premature death, heart failure (HF) has been widely implicated in a range of cardiac diseases, such as myocardial infarction or ischemia, hypertension, and cardiomyopathy.  The current therapies for HF management involve mainly long-term drug treatment or implantation of a mechanical device, such as a left-ventricular assist device. This review presents a new strategy for HF management: stem cell-based therapy.  Brief Report:  Clinical trials of stem cell-based therapy have demonstrated the efficacy of injecting exogenous stem cells into the myocardium to alleviate HF and to improve the cardiac function of patients.  Conclusion:  Stem cell-based therapy has the potential to replace existing therapeutics, improving prognosis in patients with chronic HF. ```

Haiti's top prosecutor on Friday denied reports that charges have been dropped against nine of the 10 American missionaries accused of kidnapping children after a devastating earthquake hit the nation in January. Attorney General Joseph Manes was responding to news from the office of U.S. Sen Jim Risch, R-Idaho, whose staff on Thursday said the charges had been dropped against all but one of the Baptist missionaries. Group leader Laura Silsby remains in a Haitian jail. Risch spokesman Kyle Hines said the senator had been contacted by officials at the U.S. State Department, confirming that the kidnapping charges against the other nine were dropped. However, Manes said that information was "absolutely incorrect." He said that under Haitian law, all charges against the 10 Americans stand until the examining judge, Bernard Saint-Vil, renders his final decision on whether to proceed to trial. Risch's communications director, Brad Hoaglun, said: "We are standing by what we were orginally told by the State Department. We did, however, ask the State Department to reconfirm for us, and we are waiting that response."

This was the coldest month in the U.S. in more than 20 years. This week is not off to the coldest possible start for February, but it is pretty darn close. With the exception of the deepening trough over western North America and the ridge over the East Coast, there is very little in the way of a mid-latitude circulation. The lack of any flow aloft is a big reason why the western and eastern U.S. have had such extreme cold this week. A broad area of high pressure centered over the East Coast (shown in gray in the upper right of this image) is suppressing the jet stream. It also has deepened and strengthened the already unusually deep trough to its west, causing record cold. (See the lower left box for a detailed discussion of the trough.) This is what we've been talking about for the past 10 days, a polar vortex that has a tendency to send plumes of frigid air south. Plumes are moving southeast away from the polar vortex. The government definition of affordable housing states it must be provided at a level at which the mortgage payments on the property should be more than would be paid in rent on council housing, but below market levels.

In 2004, then Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott announced plans to build homes for just £60,000.

Article: Transport Secretary Chris Grayling says BA can lease nine Qatar A320 and 321 planes and crew after advice from the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA).

   BA will use the staffed planes to minimise flight cancellations and passenger disruption from Saturday.

   The 16-day strike was prompted by what Unite union calls BA's "poverty pay".

   The long-running industrial action concerns around 2,000 of the airline's mixed-fleet staff who, if they joined since 2010, fly short and long-haul routes mainly from Heathrow airport and earn less than cabin crew on earlier agreements.

   The airline has already cancelled a small number of flights from Heathrow and merged others, but the leasing deal with Qatar means BA will be able to get the vast majority of passengers to their destinations.

   A spokeswoman for the carrier said: "We will operate 99.5% of our schedule. Our Oneworld partner, Qatar Airways, will be operating a small number of short-haul flights on our behalf."

Chris Grayling, the Transport Secretary, has approved British Airways leasing nine Qatari aircraft on a short-term basis to reduce the number of flight cancellations during the Unite union strike that starts tomorrow. The airline's chief executive, Alex Cruz, requested the planes for what will be the longest walkout at the carrier for almost 40 years. Unite also wanted the Civil Aviation Authority to recommend blocking the deal as it was said to break European Union regulations - but on Friday the union's general secretary, Len McCluskey, urged BA staff not to strike during the summer holidays. Unite had previously called off planned action at London’s Gatwick airport. It accused the airline of removing concessions and perks for staff that took part in previous strike action. The union's national officer Oliver Richardson said the decision to strike now was "a last resort because BA was unwilling to negotiate with Unite in good faith" for the best part of a year. BA's chief executive said: "We have no confidence that Unite can deliver a reliable service to our customers during their strike." Mr Cruz said: "Over and above our contingency plans, we are using our

Wenger admitted on Thursday that he has no idea what FFP means.   ```   For the text of the article, see below:   Arsene Wenger says Football Fair Play rules are complicated   Article by Simon Coates for MailOnline    Published: 12:38 EST, 2 Mar 2015 | Updated: 01:46 EST, 3 Mar 2015   Share Share

FFP has been part of UEFA’s agenda for several years and is the process of bringing the spending of clubs in-line with the income of a club. The concept was that teams should not live ‘beyond their means’ i.e. have income that is sufficient to fund their playing expenditure. This is something that had been enforced from an administration viewpoint. In my view this was needed, some clubs such as Portsmouth had over stretched and got into financial difficulties. However we must also remember that FFP was introduced in a more stable period economically. It is also worth noting that FFP is not new for UEFA it has been present for years in their youth teams competitions.   FFP was introduced for all UEFA clubs in 2012. Club’s first season’s results were used in 2011-2012 (referred to as the Break Even Point or BEP). The concept of FFP was that a Club’s BEP would provide sufficient money to cover their expenditure. That Club would then be allowed to offset that income with certain amounts of expenditure i.e. money from broadcasting rights, playing rights, transfer fees, merchandise, sponsorship etc

In a nutshell, Financial Fair Play (FFP) is a set of regulations, which the Union of European Football Associations (UEFA) adopted in 2011, which restricts clubs' spending depending on their revenue and wage bill. FFP is part of UEFA's efforts to stop clubs overspending, and ensure that their books are in order. The policy was a response to the deep financial crisis suffered by clubs in Spain and England due to the financial crash of 2008-2009. When FFP was adopted in 2011 it was hoped the policy would help to bring an end to some of the financial irregularities which had become common place in some football clubs across Europe. Initially, a soft sanction period was in place, where clubs were penalised with a partial prohibition of the sale of club's players to a certain transfer window, depending on how much they were out of the profitability requirements. For the 2013-2014 season, UEFA tightened up the policy, bringing in the following sanctions for clubs who have breached FFP requirements: * €30 million fine and 1-year prohibition for sale in transfer market

  ## What is the African Diaspora ?

  African diaspora, broadly, is defined by the African Union Commission as "peoples of African origin living outside the continent, irrespective of their citizenship and nationality and who are willing to contribute to the development of the continent and the building of the African Union." Globally, Africans in the diaspora are spread out across the continents. In North America, there are 39 million from the African Diaspora; 113 million in Latin America; 13.6 million in the Caribbean; and 3.5 million in Europe, the World Bank estimates. The African Diaspora is not a monolithic group.

  ## Economic impact of African Diaspora

  The economic impact of the African diaspora is vast. In 2020 alone, African diasporans sent in $88 billion in remittances home, according to the World Bank's latest diaspora remittance statistics. These transfers help stabilize livelihoods, maintain families, build communities and contribute

A study with two simple questions asked respondents about the nature of their contact with Africa, the level of contact with people in Africa and the type of exchange. It concludes that although most diasporans have contact with their home country, not all are engaged in any form of civic engagement, and there is a clear disconnect in the degree of contact and the nature of that contact.

During the Renaissance, geography was largely confined to the study of the world's surface features, and was concerned mostly with the collection of useful information. During the Enlightenment, however, the focus switched to exploring causation. The Enlightenment brought with it more complex theories about society and humanity. Geography, then, was enriched with this new perspective, and the discipline started to investigate how and why things were as they were. [1]
The main geographers of this period were the philosophers and writers Montesquieu and Rousseau, who focused on the idea of society and how geography had shaped it. They, however, worked in an epoch where travel was very difficult and most geographical ideas and facts came solely from books. The worldviews of the ancient and medieval worlds were not really present during this period, at least not in a direct way. The philosophers thought that humans had always been present from the outset, and thus thought that the ancient world was always very human in its character. The Age UK report says a failure by government to provide adequate social care has cost the economy £177 a week per carer. Motorists are to be hit with a £1 charge every time they drop off family or friends at Aberdeen International Airport and they will face a fine if they linger for over 10 minutes. The plan has been met with anger from visitors and taxi drivers but airport officials insist the fee and £30 parking fine are necessary to reduce congestion and improve safety in drop-off zones. Drivers will be monitored with an automatic number plate recognition (ANPR) system when the charges come into effect on January 7, The Press and Journal reported. Motorists will be hit with a £30 fine if they stay for longer than 10 minutes in the drop-off zone . Carol Benzie, Aberdeen airport’s managing director, told the newspaper that management are concerned about the safety of visitors and staff. She said: ‘An increase in traffic using the airport has resulted in some examples of dangerous behaviour among drivers and the new system will allow us to better manage that behaviour.’ But the plan has been blasted by non-airport taxi drivers, who say they were not consulted before the charges were announced. A woman has lost her fight to live after suffering a rare complication during childbirth , with her baby saved for her in her last moments. 26-year-old Kymberlie Shepherd gave birth to her first son, Kyden Thomas Bede Kelly, last Thursday but just minutes after his birth she succumbed to an amniotic fluid embolism. The rare condition occurred as the pregnant dance teacher gave birth to her son, and she was taken from the labour ward to the trauma room at Joondalup Hospital in Perth. Her partner, Wayde Kelly, was told she had no brain activity and at 12.15pm that his fiancee  of five years would not survive. The couple did not even know what an amniotic fluid embolism was and were shocked that something so tragic could happen to them. Baby Kyden stayed by his mother's side, breathing in her scent for hours following the trauma while the staff at the hospital did everything they could to save Ms Shepherd's life. The latest research, published in the journal Nature Medicine, may lead to bacterial treatments in which germs are intentionally fed to infants.
    The scientists found that when newborn mice were exposed to allergens they were better able to ward off asthma. Other studies have already shown that airway exposure to bacteria can be effective at controlling allergy-driven airway inflammation in adult mice, the scientists said.
    The team, led by Dr Benjamin Marsland, from the University of Lausanne in Switzerland, wrote: 'Our current study indicates that such treatments could be greatly optimized by targeting the narrow developmental window that exists following birth, or by targeting specific molecules. 'A key future step will be to translate these findings to human infants.'

    Asthma is an inflammatory disorder of the lungs that affects 5.5 million Britons, including 1.1 million children. It is the result of a misfiring response by the body's immune system that makes the airways inflamed, narrow and overly responsive to commonplace allergens, such as pollen, dust, mold spores, pet fur or dander. ## Health leaders plan to boost mental health care

Health leaders, including NHS England chief executive Simon Stevens and the Care Quality Commission's chief executive, have pledged to put mental health on the same footing as physical health.
Speaking at the launch of a mental health taskforce report commissioned by NHS England, Mr Stevens said: "It matters for the NHS, of course, but it also matters crucially to each and every one of us."
He said the NHS England's five-year plan would "fully endorse the report and the measures it recommends".
The health services taskforce report says an estimated three-quarters of people go without help.
The report says urgent improvements need to be made, and suggests better mental health care would save £8bn a year.
Around three-quarters of people with mental health problems receive no help at all.
Prime Minister David Cameron has said more needs to be done, committing £1bn extra a year by 2020.
The government says this will help treat more than a million people a year.
The funds from the £8.4bn a year

Mental illness is a leading cause of disability and a major driver of inequality in this country. More people than ever - about 1 in 4 - say they have experienced a mental health problem at some point in their lives, but most get no help - only about 17% of those who have a problem go to the GP for help, or see a mental health specialist. Even for those with severe and disabling problems - the report says up to 20% of the population - they face a postcode lottery and a system that is more geared to crisis intervention rather than prevention and early intervention. The taskforce suggests that one in 20 people with mental health problems would have to die to reflect the disparity between their treatment and treatment of physical illnesses. As well as money, the report also focuses attention on the shortage of mental health staff - with only 244 more per each million of the population than in 2007/8. The report is the fulfilment of a commitment by the government - as outlined in the 2010 Coalition Agreement - to prioritise mental health care. Health secretary Jeremy Hunt has already called it ground-breaking - and a "huge leap forward

The Government's new strategy on mental health funding was outlined to MPs.
The strategy is intended to help children with a mental illness.
The UK government is planning on a £15m increase in funding for children's mental health.
The money will help improve the health of children in their early years.
NHS England is planning on a £1bn increase in funding for children's mental illness.
The increase will help improve health services for people in their early years.
The funds will be spent on a range of services including:

â¢ Online therapy

The UK government will invest in a "transformation fund" which will fund NHS staff to improve the quality of care.
The Government's strategy is intended to improve the quality of NHS clinical staff.

A British mother is facing the prospect of spending Christmas behind bars over her daughter's name after a judge warned her that she would be jailed in the New Year.

Anarchy and beauty: William Morris and his legacy at the National Portrait Gallery until 22 April 2012, £10-[15]] This was, I'm told, the first portrait made of the Pre-Raphaelite painter William Morris since his death in 1896. (The portrait itself dates back to 1887. Morris would be very much alive indeed by today) He was more than a painter, though. Indeed, as a groundbreaking new exhibition on Morris reveals, he was not only a socialist firebrand who almost single-handedly sparked the arts and crafts movement, he also had decidedly risqué tastes in gardening implements. I can't post the pictures here, but a garden implement on show at the exhibition shows Adam and Eve cavorting before its roller. The full article is:  William Morris was the most famous, respected and influential of the Pre-Raphaelite artists – and he was not afraid to use his profile to promote his radical ideas and left-wing political beliefs. At least, that is, until he and his fellow socialists decided to put their principles into practice by staging demonstrations on Oxford Street. Morris wrote to a fellow socialist friend: ‘I have never felt so ashamed in my life. . . Oxford Street is the very place that one would choose for a demonstration, I admit. . . One must own that the idea of throwing bombs on Oxford Street is not a bad one, but, to my mind, for the present, it is more important to do as little harm to the public as possible.’  So began William Morris' love-hate relationship with the public. Though he was never keen to see his work mass-produced – in keeping with his belief in the craftsmanship of the medieval era – Morris recognised the importance of getting his message across to the masses.  The diaries of William Morris are on display at the National Portrait Gallery  The diaries of William

Speaker's role is to act as an umpire, representing the interests of MPs to the monarch. [ZAF] Zimbabwe's highest court orders elections by July 31 2013 by June 2013 (AFP, 24-05-2013) - Zimbabwe's highest court ordered President Robert Mugabe's government to hold elections by July 31, citing the constitution's time frame for parliamentary elections, the state-run Herald newspaper reported on Thursday. The ruling follows a request from a lawyer with an opposition movement, Lovemore Madhuku, to ensure an election by June 29 before the incumbent parliament's term expired. "The elections must be held between the 12th of June and the 31st of July," Judge Godfrey Chidyausiku was quoted as saying by the Herald. The court ruling is another sign of how the southern African nation, where Mugabe has stayed in power for three decades, has been rocked from the political consensus that was struck after troubled 2008 presidential elections. Since these elections, the unity government has been fractious. [END] ---- Zimbabwe - 2013/5/

The Department of Homeland Security has more contractors working for it than full-time employees, a situation two members of Congress said Tuesday was "unacceptable, untenable and unsustainable." Sen. Joseph Lieberman, the chairman of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, and ranking Republican Susan Collins said they were "astounded" to learn there are more than 200,000 contractor employees at the department. The civilian work force of Homeland Security numbers 188,000, according to an estimate provided to the senators by Homeland Security. In a letter sent Tuesday to the agency's secretary, Janet Napolitano, Lieberman and Collins said the figure "raises the question of whether DHS itself is in charge of its programs and policies, or whether it inappropriately has ceded core decisions to contractors." Youths have rioted on the streets of Athens and other Greek cities for the past three days. Stores and cars have been torched, barricades erected and rioters have fought running battles with police. Athens riot police come under attack near the capital's main police station Sunday. The unrest came after police shot dead teenager Alexandros Grigoropoulos, 15, who they allege was about to throw a fuel-filled device at them, as a gang of youths pelted a patrol vehicle. What has been the political reaction to the unrest? The Greek government, led by Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis' center-right New Democracy party since 2004, has appealed for calm. Interior minister Prokopis Pavlopoulos and his deputy tendered their resignations, but this offer was rejected by Karamanlis. As the funeral passed through a downtown Athens street, police fired tear gas, water cannon and stun grenades to disperse the crowd. Grigoropoulos is the 136th to die at the hands of police in the last 34 years. Article: Undercover FBI agents in Florida found what investigators believe is a stolen Henri Matisse painting that had been missing for nearly a decade, officials said Wednesday. Two suspects were arrested in Miami Beach after trying to sell "Odalisque in Red Pants," valued at $3 million, federal prosecutors said. The painting was stolen from a Venezuelan art museum in 2002, the statement said. Pedro Antonio Marcuello Guzman, 46, of Miami and Maria Martha Elisa Ornelas Lazo, 50, of Mexico City are charged with transporting and possessing the stolen painting, the FBI said. If convicted, they face up to 10 years in prison. Undercover agents made the arrest Tuesday at Loews Miami Beach Hotel, CNN affiliate WPLG reported. Marcuello set up the deal, told agents he knew the painting was stolen and asked them to pay $740,000 for it, the FBI and federal prosecutors said Wednesday, citing an affidavit filed in support of a criminal complaint. Ornelas was a Mexican national who worked as a vacation rental agent in Acapulco, according to WPLG

Amid heightened tensions with North Korea, the United States and South Korea on Sunday began joint military exercises. The military exercises, dubbed Invincible Spirit, are scheduled to run through Wednesday in waters off South Korea to demonstrate the alliance's resolve. In addition to the 8,000 personnel involved, military officials say, the exercises will include 20 ships and submarines and about 200 aircraft. The U.S. Defense Department said the drills are in response to the sinking of the South Korean warship Cheonan and are intended to send a strong message to Pyongyang to stop "provocative and warlike acts." The drills will include anti-sub infiltration exercises, said Cmdr. Jeff Davis of the U.S. 7th Fleet. "The anti-sub-infiltration exercise works like this: if a sub is coming in to attack a ship, the military finds it and prosecutes it," he said. Davis said there was a "renewed desire" and urgency to focus on the exercise after the Cheonan sinking. ``` Links: URLs are not output automatically, but must be specified explicitly using one

The 60's are long gone for many of us but even at 70 odd , I feel young (and it’s all relative anyway) because every day I meet young people who were born in the 80’s or 90’s or even more recently and I wonder how they could be old (I'm not the first person to have asked this question by the way, someone once joked that they were probably older than they thought , only not for the same reasons…
This is not about getting old but the fact of our being born in a certain epoch which affects how we look at life and in this case, the fact of having been born in the 60's and of being on my own for a big part of the time which led me to think in this direction.
But that doesn't stop me from feeling young. Even though you are over 50 , there are plenty of things you can do if you love life and want to live it to the fullest. So the next time somebody tells you that you're too old for something, give them a big smile and tell them that there's no such thing as being too old to enjoy life and that your age

A spokesman for the Yorkville Endoscopy clinic gave CNN its first public statement since Rivers fell ill during a procedure. While federal privacy laws limit what medical providers can make public, the statement counters a New York newspaper report quoting an unidentified source saying a doctor made a "spur-of-the-moment" decision "to take a scalpel to a polyp-like growth on her vocal cord." "A biopsy of the vocal cords has never been performed at Yorkville Endoscopy," the clinic's statement said. Many questions have been raised about what that treatment was given and what might have gone wrong that led to the comedian's death.  Few answers have been made public because of medical privacy rules, but the New York State Health Department confirmed the agency is investigating. It found that on average more than 4,500 babies die each year (1.7%) after birth. There are about half a million (540,000) births in one week. Almost all births in the UK are planned between 37 and 42 weeks gestation.
Most babies die because of severe congenital anomalies, but many births do not involve complications. Deaths occurring after delivery are known as perinatal deaths, and 22% of these occur on the weekend.
Risks vary throughout pregnancy and the perinatal period and may reflect underlying diseases of mothers and babies, fetal abnormalities, pregnancy diseases and complications of labour or delivery; however, deaths also occur when problems of labour and/or delivery are not recognised and treated.
The aim was to review the pattern of perinatal mortality in the day and week when babies are born by exploring the weekly pattern of perinatal mortality in the UK and identifying factors linked to perinatal mortality.
Data were collected on 651,018 live births from 88 hospitals in England and Wales during 2010−

The UK experiences an NHS winter crisis every year around late November to early March.
  During this time, bed capacity is always at or over 100%, and an increasing majority of patients arriving at emergency departments must be sent home by the hospital or transferred to another facility.
  In March 2017, Prime Minister Theresa May stated "the winter crisis is not the new normal, and never will be"; however, this is widely doubted by doctors and health care workers.
  The crisis is caused by (or at least significantly exacerbated by) shortages in personnel (including doctors, surgeons, nurses, therapists, porters, and administrative staff), beds, hospital capacity, and community-based care.
  The British Association for Surgery of the Knee called the crisis a "disaster" on 1 March 2017, and warned of "massive waiting lists" and "years-long waiting times for hip and knee procedures".

The research suggests 50p as the minimum price because it will stop a bottle of beer being bought for £1 or less - the limit that retailers generally buy booze below. ```

It could prevent more than 50 alcohol-related deaths a year, with poorer people seeing most health improvements.Researchers from Sheffield University say a 50p unit price could reduce total alcohol consumption in Wales by 4%. Health Minister Mark Drakeford welcomed the report as the Welsh government plans a new law on the issue for 2015. Mr Drakeford had unveiled the proposals for a minimum 50p unit price for alcohol in a public health white paper in April. He said the research published on Monday showed it would have "significant benefits" on the nation's health, and built on the advice of the Advisory Panel on Substance Misuse published in July. It would mean fewer alcohol-related deaths and ease the burden of alcohol-related harm on the Welsh NHS, he added. It is no coincidence that as alcohol has become relatively cheaper, alcohol-related deaths and disease have increased. We will consider these findings and continue to develop our proposals with a view to introducing legislation. The proposals for a minimum 50p unit price for alcohol is part of a public health white paper published by he Welsh government in April. It could become law as part of

[A unit price floor of 50p] could prevent more than 50 alcohol-related deaths a year in Wales and result in substantial health improvements among young people from low-income households, research says.  The proposal could raise the price of a can of own-brand lager by £1.56, a bottle of own-brand white wine by £1.98 and a bottle of own-brand vodka by £4.45, says a report for the Welsh Government by Dr Shefy Thomas of Sheffield University.  That would leave a typical drinker paying about £10 more a year but the impact would be much bigger on heavier drinkers in low-income social groups, the report says.  It could reduce the number of hospital admissions by 0.6% a year, the researchers estimate.  It would also have a greater impact on alcohol sales in deprived areas and among young people, the report by Sheffield University said.  Overall it would reduce alcohol consumption by about 4%, according to the study, which also modelled the effects of a floor price of 45p.  That would leave the typical drinker about £7 a year better

Four bombings targeted bus stations in the port city of Tartous and in Jableh, a town to the north, which have until now escaped the worst of the civil war. A news agency linked to so-called Islamic State (IS) said the jihadist group was behind the attacks. Amaq cited an IS source as saying militants had targeted “gatherings of Alawites”, a reference to the heterodox Shia sect to which President Bashar al-Assad belongs. Russia - a key backer of Mr Assad - has a naval base in Tartous and an airbase near Jableh, from where it has conducted air strikes on IS targets across Syria. State media said at least 78 people were killed, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, a UK-based monitoring group put the death toll at more than 145. Amaq cited an IS source as saying militants had targeted “gatherings of Alawites”, a reference to the heterodox Shia sect to which President Bashar al-Assad belongs. ```

A good summary tells me something about the subject of the article.  - It is a summary, not a summary, of all the points it covers.  * The summary does not list the arguments for and against the article.  - It does not contain new or additional information. ### 1. Title

* **Question**: How are titles helpful?
* **Answer**:  Titles are summaries of the article. They are used to quickly get the gist of what is in the rest of the article without having to read a long sentence. They should be short enough for easy reading and scanning, but long enough to be informative.


* **Input**: 96-year-old Prince Philip admitted to hospital – as it happened
* **Output**: The title of the article is ```96-year-old Prince Philip admitted to hospital – as it happened```
* **Explanation**: The title of the article is a summary of what is mentioned in the article.

### 2. URL

* **Question**: How are URLs helpful?
* **Answer**:  For users, URLs serve as a way to find articles, locate the site publishing the article, and bookmark or share the article. For search engines, they help to better index information and return search results.


* **Input**: https://www

## The Telegraph | Prince Philip taken to hospital as precaution after 'feeling unwell'

Article: This is a 96-year-old who is reported to be in "good spirits" and who is in hospital as a "precautionary measure".

He was driven there in a car, not an ambulance, from Windsor, where he was said to have been on great form when he attended the first day of the Ascot races.

In sweltering heat on Tuesday, he was dressed in a morning suit.

The prince, like his wife and countless other people, isn't overly keen on publicising the precise nature of what ails him.

Snow, also known as white crystals, is an intricate solid material that forms in clouds or around aerosols .

- Snow is a mixture of water suspended in tiny air pockets. - Water molecules are composed of an atom of oxygen attached to two atoms of hydrogen. - Hydrogen is diaphanous, meaning that it lets light pass through its molecules but alters its path. - The effect is such that as light hits the snow, it is scattered and refracted so that the colour of the snow at any one moment in time depends on the path the sunlight has taken. In some instances, the snow can appear red. This happens when the sunlight has entered snow, been scattered and reflected back by snow crystals. Snow is an optical illusion.

If you are considering a position outside of the realm of your previous job experience, this is a good way for you to see if you would like to pursue the position, and if you think you are qualified.
- Do not include anything on your resume that is unrelated to your field, unless it is a hobby. People like to see a wide range of interests and skills, but they don't like to see everything.

I shot this picture on a cold, clear, sunny day in the Cairngorms. It's December so there was a good sprinkling of snow on the ground (as you can see!). The sun is high in the sky, meaning more than likely that the angle of the light is low which tends to make the hares' eyes 'pop' in photographs. This helps to highlight the subject of the picture and make it more interesting. I shot it on an Olympus OM-D EM1.

  The exposure was 700 ISO. 14mm. F/8. 1/400 Seconds (Hand held).

  The hare looked very cute with snow on its eyes & face. Even though it was in a good spot for an interesting photograph I am aware that photographing an animal in a zoo is not very 'wild' so always aim to avoid it if possible. However, this hare did look interesting so thought it an appropriate picture for the Wildlife Photographer of the Year awards.

The Reformatory built in 1886, which narrowly escaped demolition recently, has now been earmarked for a massive makeover. Over the next six months the building will be cleaned, redecorated, and have its huge cathedral-style windows replaced as well as having heating installed in a bid to increase tourism. Article: When it comes to getting ahead at work, it seems many women lack the confidence to ask for a pay rise or a promotion. Despite an increasingly successful corporate existence, a survey has found the glass ceiling still looms with nearly a fifth of women (17 per cent) believing it's impossible for a woman to reach senior management. A major fire is reported at a 16-story residential building located in the London neighborhood of Brixton. The fire broke out on the ground floor and quickly spread to the first and second floors of the building. A pregnant woman, a man, and a child were hospitalized with smoke inhalation. The London Fire Brigade sent ten engines and 72 firefighters to the scene of the fire. According to images from the scene, a large cloud of black smoke could be seen in the sky over London. The cause of the fire is yet to be determined.

A ramshackle garage next to a south London industrial estate has become the most expensive ever to sell in Britain after going under the hammer for £550,000 in a 'frenzied' bidding war.

The brick-built former coach house, used for years to park the Mayor of Southwark's car, sold at auction for almost triple the guide price and £150,000 more than the average house in Camberwell.

The price paid for the 'empty shell' of a building by an anonymous buyer beat the previous record, held by a garage near Harrods in Knightsbridge, west London, by £25,000.

Ehlers Danlos syndromes are a group of inherited disorders that affect connective tissue . The joints, skin and other tissues are more stretchy and weaker than normal. EDS can run in families . People with EDS are more flexible than normal and have stretchy, elastic skin. You may be born with the condition, or you may develop it in childhood or young adulthood.

  The different types of Ehlers Danlos Syndrome are named after the different symptoms and/or characteristics, but they all involve a mutation of a gene involved in making collagen, a key protein in . connective tissues.

The main differences among the subtypes are the types and locations of joint involvement as well as the severity and extent of skin involvement.

## The 4 major subtypes of EDS are:

EDS I (Hypermobile EDS, formerly known as “Classic EDS”)

EDS II (Hypermobile EDS with hyperelastic skin)

EDS III (Hypermobile EDS w/thin translucent skin or white appearance)

EDS IV-V (Kyphoscolios

Nigeria's ruling party has set its presidential primaries for next month, a spokesman said Thursday. The primaries will be held between October 18 and 20, said Rufai Alkali, a spokesman for the People's Democratic Party. A single candidate will be ratified on October 23, Alkali said. On Wednesday, President Goodluck Jonathan said he intends to run, and will make a formal declaration on Saturday. "In presenting myself for service, I make no pretense that I have a magic wand that will solve all of Nigeria's problems or that I am the most intelligent Nigerian," Jonathan wrote on his Facebook page. "Far from it. What I do promise is this. I will be a servant of all, I will give 24 hour of my time everyday to the service of our great country Nigeria. I will be transparent in my service, a transparent leader is a selfless leader. I will build a solid and sustainable economy to empower every Nigerian and transform us into a new golden age, a new golden opportunity. I will be hard working, focused, committed, determined and a leader that will not take no for an answer. ``` ```  The detailed summary

Nigeria's 2015 presidential election will be the sixth in the country's history and the first time that an incumbent president is seeking re-election since a new political order was established in 1999. President Goodluck Jonathan is expected to be the main candidate of the governing party, the People's Democratic Party (PDP), which has ruled Nigeria since 1999.

The election will take place over a 1-month period in March. If none of the candidates can win the majority of the vote, the top 2 candidates will meet in a run-off vote in April (1).
The election is expected to be particularly competitive, with up to 8 candidates considered potential front-runners (2). In 2007, Jonathan (then the vice president) won by less than 1% of the vote, so with a large field this may lead to a more intense contest. Jonathan has been criticized during his presidency for failing to tackle corruption, and the government's handling of a militant insurgency in the northeast of the country, among other issues.

New Order reinvented their back catalogue on the first night of the Manchester International Festival.
They played the first of five concerts with a 12-strong synthesiser ensemble.
Meanwhile, the thrillingly anarchic 14-strong hip-hop crew Levelz showed why they're being talked up as part of the next wave of Manchester heroes.
Together, they showed off different sides of the city's scene to open the biennial city-wide festival.
New Order took over one of the old Granada TV studios and pushed their status as synth-pop idols to the extreme by recruiting a dozen synthesiser players from the Royal Northern College of Music.
Those synth players were installed behind the regular band members in booths in a double-decker structure created by artist Liam Gillick.
Each booth was fronted by Venetian blind-style slats that opened and closed in formation as visuals were projected onto them.
The gig was largely a hit-free zone, with the group preferring to delve into rarities from their 40 years as Joy Division and then New Order rather than play their best-known tracks

Another patient crashed her car trying to avoid a pedestrian who had wandered into the street playing the game.
Researchers say these cases show the potential for "distraction-related injury and death" with the rise in popularity of games such as Pokemon Go.
Both patients were admitted to a trauma centre with serious injuries.
Researchers from the US state of Arizona said it was a challenge to know how to categorise the injuries, which they describe as "augmented reality application related injuries".
The two cases, reported in Oxford Medical Case Reports, are among the first of their kind to appear in a medical journal.
Although the report said these sorts of apps encouraged players to exercise, it also warned of a “sinister side” because they encouraged players to become distracted.
Co-author David Armstrong, professor of surgery at the University of Arizona, said: "Our world is filled with digital distractions increasing at a near logarithmic rate - both in work and in play.
"What we have to figure out as a society and, frankly, as a species, is how to dose these distractions to help make our lives better and not shorter."

MSP's said they were surprised this bill was only for home to school transport and not school trips .``` Please read the full article and follow it for relevant updates.

"
The Scottish Parliament has given its backing to Gillian Martin’s Backbench Bill to make it a legal requirement for all Scottish minibuses and coaches, used exclusively for pupils, to have seat belts fitted.
The rural economy and connectivity committee welcomed the Bill and suggested the Bill be extended to cover buses used for school trips.
Just over half of Scotland’s councils have the requirement as part of their school transport contracts.

The committee highlighted that the Bill did not require that seatbelts were worn.
Labour MSP Neil Bibby said 74% of pupils at a school he visited said they were unlikely to wear, or would not wear, seat belts.

SNP MSP Stewart Stevenson said that requiring the fitting of seatbelts in school buses was something the Scottish Parliament could legislate for.
The law that would enforce wearing those seatbelts lay elsewhere.

Lib Dem MSP Mike Rumbles said he was “astonished” that this was not already a law and that all 32 local authorities had not specified this in their contracts.
”

```The legislation requiring the use of seat belts does not apply to dedicated school buses that local authorities provide. This was highlighted in 2009 where two sisters were killed near Fyvie when returning home from school in Aberdeenshire.

```
`Motor vehicles- Seat belts - Private members bills - Gillian Martin`
```In August 2020 MSP Gillian Martin brought a bill to make it a legal requirement for seat belts to be fitted on all dedicated home-to-school transport.

```

```

Gillian Martin's (SNP) Backbench Bill was reported on unamended to the Rural Economy and Connectivity Committee (REC Committee), where Committee members raised concerns over the lack of enforcement provisions in the legislation.

They also discussed extending the scope of the legislation beyond home-to-school journeys and raising concerns over the lack of funding available to local authorities to ensure that seat belts are on school buses, and for more detailed evidence to be included in the Bill.

The Committee agreed that it was not possible to accept more amendments to the Bill. It agreed to ask the Scottish School Bus Association to write to the Committee with a view to supporting the Bill. The Committee agreed to seek technical advice on the issues of enforcement and funding.

If you do you could try turning off your browser's extension (usually an icon in the address bar) and give it another try. Or, try a different browser (Chrome or Firefox are recommended). If you still get the 'No parser-plugin detected' error message, it is likely that either your browser is blocked by your company (contact your IT department) or your country has a very strict government policy that is preventing the communication of sensitive text.
By default, the Markdown editor is activated when the Markdown button is clicked, and is disabled otherwise. Markdown can be activated on-demand using the hotkey Ctrl-Shift-M.
Markdown Here buttons can be displayed on web pages. This is very useful for showing a Markdown button next to a textarea or WYSIWYG

# How to read the summary in plain text
The summary in plain text is not a real plain text: it uses a specific format (mark down). The first character before a text (for example, `**bold**` for "bold", *italic* for italic) define an "action" on the text. See [Markdown Cheat Sheet](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/wiki/Markdown-Cheatsheet) on how to format your text to make it in the best summary. This is an example to format the text you want to summaries:

* First, **copy the text you want to summarize** (not it) into a text file.
* Second, **clean all the format of your text (spaces character before or after, unordered list, ordered list, ...)** in order for the webservice to summarize only the text
* Third, **check the summary**. If your summary is wrong, retry with the previous **clean** version.

Here you can see an **example

There was no surprise of announcement from former Secretary Hillary. But there are a great deal of things to take-away from her speech. Clinton feels most comfortable in feminism. The former secretary of state is confident about her future. ```

Dogs often get trapped in cars if they are overheated so as part of
'dog-awareness-week', it is really important to make sure that cars are
never left locked and that dogs are not left alone in cars during hot
weather. They need shade and fresh water, if possible.
If a dog is stuck in a car in a very hot place then first check that
others owners or authorities have not already called to have the car
brought to a different location with cooler temperatures. Otherwise
call the police if it is possible and alert security personnel (such
as park rangers, wardens or even the local fire brigade as in the
case of this East Anglian Dog).
Remember also to take a photo and record the numberplate if there is
no identification. Remember that the numberplate should be photographed
under angle from a sideway so the licence plate can easily be seen,
and it might be useful to check for some ID marks on the car - for
instance, the manufacturer might have a particular type of lock or
other identification markings that can be useful for the police or
fire brigade. This should be taken at the same

Alison Sharland, 46, accepted £10.35million from AppSense founder Charles Sharland two years ago after their marriage of 17 years broke down. She agreed to the payout thinking it was worth half his fortune - yet his stake in the firm was estimated wildly higher at £150million soon afterwards, London's Court of Appeal heard. Students at the University of Glasgow spent the past week removing hundreds of tonnes of mud from the Cochno Stone at Faiffley in Clydebank.```

The Cochno Stone dates from the Neolithic and its rock art has the most complex, dense carvings of its kind found anywhere in Britain. It predates the mysterious Stonehenge complex by 1,5000 years, making it older than the pyramids of Egypt. The stone lies on a mound called Cochno Hill and is surrounded by Neolithic earthworks (some in the form of henge).
The Cochno hillfort is a large, flat topped, fortified enclosure, on a raised plateau in Duntocher Moor. It is one of Scotland’s largest hillforts, measuring almost 150m from side to side.
The first part of the archaeological work involves removing the approximately 2,000 tonnes of peat that had been covering the monument. This will take place from Wednesday-Sunday.

Once the peat is removed and the monument cleared, Glasgow University is due to scan the Cochno Stone for the next two weeks to capture the rock-art carvings.

A fire crew from Clydebank in Scotland has been drafted in to help clean mud from the surface of the Cochno Stone, a Neolithic slab which is covered with dozens of cup and ring marks. Over the past week, university students have dug away about 80 tonnes of mud which was covering the stone, in a joint project between the Factum Foundation and the University of Glasgow.  Specialists in photography and mapping have also been documenting the stone in 3D.

  A spokeswoman from Historic Environment Scotland said: "After our consultation with archaeologists and other experts, it has been agreed that the stone will be re-buried. We are working through that process at the moment."

  The Cochno Stone is located at Faiffley on a hill above the River Clyde, on the north-east side of Clydebank. It is 3.89m (12ft 9in) wide and 1.79m (5ft 11in) high at its highest point. Although no-one now knows what the symbols on the stone mean, it is generally believed to have spiritual significance to the people who carved it about

## What happened during the criminal investigation at the European Level?

We should be clear on what is the most important question to be answered in this blog post. The answer is simple, and it is just a matter of applying the criminal law, or in other words, to follow the basic steps of a criminal investigation, which is to be:

## What happened in the Czech Republic?

We should remember that it is not about the Czech Republic being responsible for the crime or not.
The point is:

## What was the difference between Poland and the Czech Republic regarding criminal responsibility of the suspects?

This is the main question, which requires further research.
But there is an answer to this.
The main difference between the two countries in terms of criminal law is that the Czech Republic has no legal framework for handling extradition cases.
This means, that the Czech Republic did not have any procedures to deal with this type of case, and thus it will be up to the European Parliament to decide whether or not to ratify European Arrest Warrant.
European Arrest Warrant is the key tool for making sure that criminals cannot hide in Europe anymore.

In China, salesman Luo Zili has created a new portable mobile house that he can carry with him around the busy streets of Shangluo City in Shaanxi Province. He created the mobile house out of bamboo, plastic film and sheets, which he then fitted out with a mattress, bedding and even a portable stove. Luo built the prototype of the house last year for around RMB220 (£24) . He can be see taking a stroll wearing the house and even resting it on his back. The idea came about as a protest against the price of property in China . Luo claims the house is easy to carry and can be dismantled and rebuilt within 30 minutes. He uses it as a place to stay at during his work week, which sees him roaming the city and nearby areas selling home appliances, clothing and bicycles. Luo is the first person to design this type of mobile house, yet due to rising property prices, it’s a style of home that could possibly become a real alternative option for city dwellers. A travelling salesman in China takes his whole house wherever he goes by simply picking it up and hoisting it onto his back. Mr Liu, who goes around the city of Liuzhou in the Guangxi region, selling recyclable bottles, said building his portable home five years ago saved him money on his journey. He said: 'I can move anywhere I want to go. It's an easy decision. It saves me a lot of money on the journey,' he said. 'I feel free, I can go wherever I want to go and I live on my own.' Forgetting to pack something becomes impossible with this man's method of packing up and moving on. The structure weighs around 60kg and is made of bamboo poles, plastic film and sheets. It contains all his belongings and a place to sleep. A passer-by saw the man on the road lugging his house on his back and stopped to grab a shot. He said: 'If my job wasn't so hard, I would want to choose a life like this.'

Private mode. In computing, a private mode is a browser mode that disables tracking and data storage or deletes any information that is typically stored from that session. For example, when using a browser's private mode feature, browsing history, cookies and temporary Internet files are not stored. Web pages opened by a web browser in private mode will not be stored in the browsing history so that a user may browse anonymously in online communities or on websites. Most major web browsers, such as Safari, Firefox, Internet Explorer, Chrome, Opera, Google Chrome and Tor Browser, have implemented a form of private browsing. In 1999, Opera introduced the feature, calling it "always clean browsing." Internet Explorer introduced the feature under the name "InPrivate mode" in September 2005,[1] followed by Safari in June 2009, Firefox in February 2010[2] and Chrome, in March 2010, calling it "Incognito mode". Tor Browser

This isn't new, but it is useful. Google has patented a system that can switch the browser to private mode when a site is asking for personal information like emails. On Google’s Chrome, that’s known as Incognito Mode. This is a privacy feature that’s been around for years. You can also enable incognito mode for certain websites only. For example, when you launch Facebook or Twitter, Chrome will launch the service in Incognito Mode. This is a privacy feature that’s been around for years. ## How to start private browsing

With Incognito Mode, your activity won't be saved to your browser's history, so anyone who uses your computer later won't see the websites you've been browsing. Incognito also blocks your Chrome browser from saving cookies when you close your incognito window.

## Incognito Mode doesn't hide you from everything

Keep in mind that your online activity is still visible to websites you visit, your employer, or your school, and a total stranger sitting next to you on the train can see your activity on their screen as well. Also, some websites save certain information, like your IP address, so a forensic expert might be able to determine what sites you've visited.

## When to stop using private browsing

Private Browsing helps prevent your browser from storing data

Police will use specialist interviewers to speak to school children in South Auckland who witnessed one of their peers being stabbed by another student.

Police said the 11-year-old boy remains in a stable condition with a head injury in a children's ward at Auckland's Starship Hospital.

Police and Child, Youth and Family staff will speak with the child today, and officers have begun speaking with other schoolchildren who witnessed the fight.

`The Government says the gender pay gap is still too high despite having fallen steadily from 54.2% in 1964 to 18.1% in 2016. The government uses data that includes full-time and part-time workers in order to compare like with like. The ONS collects data from the Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings. It is collected on the last weekend of April to allow people on different patterns of pay, e.g. teachers in different months of the year, to be included. The pay gap is calculated by taking the median male earnings of the earnings in the survey (50% above; 50% below) and subtracting the median female earnings. The ONS says that a smaller gap of difference between the numbers of men and women with high earnings doesn't necessarily mean less of a gap in pay, other factors can be a factor. This might include men and women having different jobs, or working different hours. Pay data for part-time and full-time workers shows that part-time workers have a lower median hourly earnings than full-time workers. As one of the sporting world's biggest stars, Usain Bolt would have expected rigorous questioning from the media about his current form or decision to only run the relay at the Glasgow Commonwealth Games.

The discovery of cracks in two more A380 wings after a similar discovery two weeks ago has sent the world's biggest jetliner back to the drawing board. The latest cracking problem was discovered in two A380 aircraft during routine two-year inspections, Airbus said. While the first set of findings related to the upper wing, the second set affected a location farther down the wing. Airbus said the cracks discovered in two aircraft will not likely affect airline schedules as the airlines have two back-up A380s. Mosquirix vaccine safe and effective against deadly childhood disease
Medicine and health: malaria

The European Medicines Agency gave a positive scientific opinion after assessing its safety and effectiveness.
It represents a 'green light' for the Mosquirix jab, developed by GlaxoSmithKline.
The World Health Organization will consider later this year whether to recommend it for children, among whom trials have yielded mixed results.
Malaria kills around 584,000 people a year worldwide, most of them children under five in sub-Saharan Africa.
Mosquirix, otherwise known as the RTS,S vaccine, is the first against a parasitic infection in humans.
Dr Ripley Ballou, head of research at GSK vaccines, said: "This is a hugely significant moment. I've been working on this vaccine for 30 years and this is a dream come true."
The company has not revealed the price of the vaccine, but has pledged not to make a profit from it.
It has been designed specifically to combat malaria infection in children in Africa and will not be licensed for travellers.

It may be the first Marmite egg in the shops, but some scientists have found a natural way to spread the love on the nation’s toast, which could give the company some competition. The new study from the University of South Australia in Adelaide found that it was possible to make a vegan version that could rival or even outdo the original - and that’s not Marmite at all. Researchers created a yeast fermentation solution that yielded a sticky black liquid with a nutty, savoury flavour. Scientists found that the yeast they fermented, named X213-16A, could be combined with vitamin B12 to make a liquid more savoury than the original. But while the product did not contain any yeast it contained vitamins B3 and B12, which are usually present in the food yeast, says .

Scientists have developed a handheld device that can be used to diagnose urinary tract infections within the hour. The device can detect bacteria directly from urine samples four times more rapidly than traditional laboratory methods, they say.
A common problem with urinary tract infections (UTIs) is that doctors often have to "carpet bomb" patients with antibiotics because they don't have all the necessary test results beforehand.
The Norwich Research Park team developed the test to improve the diagnosis of UTIs.

Eunice Kennedy Shriver, the sister of President John F. Kennedy and a champion of the disabled who founded the Special Olympics, died Tuesday, the Special Olympics said. She was 88.

# Bio

Born on July 10, 1921, in Brookline, Massachusetts, Shriver was the fifth of nine children to Joseph P. and Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy. She emerged from the long shadow of siblings John F. Kennedy, Robert F. Kennedy and Sen. Edward M. Kennedy as the founder of the Special Olympics, which started as a summer day camp in her backyard in 1962. Today, 3.1 million people with mental disabilities participate in 228 programs in 170 nations, according to the Special Olympics.

``She was the light of our lives, a mother, wife, grandmother, sister and aunt who taught us by example and with passion what it means to live a faith-driven life of love and service to others,'' the Shriver family said Tuesday in a statement. ``For each of us, she often seemed to stop time itself.''

"South America's second-largest economy has been through so many different economic policies and experiments in the past two decades that a whole new vocabulary has sprung up to explain day-to-day economic transactions. Buenos Aires' main commercial street, Calle Florida, now has dozens of "little trees" (arbolitos), the name given to black-market traders who buy and sell dollars openly in the streets. They stand around like bushes holding up green leaves (dollar bills). Some traders prefer to "make puree" ("hacer puré"), which is to buy dollars from the government and resell them to the "caves" ("cuevas"), the illegal exchange rate shops that deal with "blue" (black-market dollars). 3rd December, 2016 US Gross domestic product (GDP), sometimes called “net national product,” is the market value of all final goods and services produced in a country in a given period of time. GDP is usually estimated on an annual and quarterly basis. Yearly growth rates that exceed 3% are often viewed as being healthy and supportive of job creation and income advances; some economists, such as Thomas J. Sargent, however, argue that the rate is lower than it would be absent the economic distortions brought on by government intervention. Quarterly growth data are highly variable; many macroeconomic indicators, such as the purchasing manager indices, are considered by many investors and economists to be leading economic indicators. A large variety of goods and services are included in the measurements, most notably: Consumer expenditures on services (e.g., transportation) and goods (e.g., clothing). In January 2010 the Peak District National Park Authority established a "woodland asset management process'' after 11 years of legal wrangling over access rights. To date the authority has disposed of 47 woodlands, totalling 140 hectares, to community groups or local councils that agreed to restrict public access across them. The authority now says that 74 more woods will be sold off later in the year. ```

  Link Source :: https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-derbyshire-42997300

The Peak District National Park Authority (PDNPA) said it was 'reducing liabilities' at a time of budget cuts. It said the areas were small and would be sold with restrictions on their use - and a similar number would be sold later in the year. The Woodland Trust said it would monitor the situation closely to make sure safeguards were in place. All national parks have been facing large cuts in grants - the PDNPA has lost £3.5m in funding since 2010 - a cut of a cut of 36.5%. Jane Chapman, assistant director at the authority, said: 'Having established or improved these woods - often by reclaiming former rubbish tips or quarry sites - then protected and maintained them over many years, we have fulfilled our primary objective as a national park. We now want to return these natural assets to the community, as we are reducing our liabilities at a time of budget reductions.' The Dyson Hard is effectively a cross between an old-style mop and a vacuum cleaner. The hi-tech device uses a wet wipe on a pad on the bottom to clean away stains on hard floors, removing dried on kitchen spills. Separately, there is a vacuum which sucks up all the toast crumbs and accumulated dust. Arguably, the new £249.99 device is the biggest innovation since Sir James Dyson first launched his bagless vacuum cleaners 20 years ago. Importantly, it taps in to the growing desire among householders for cordless machines, which are not tied up in a cat's cradle of cables. The Dyson Hard also serves as an alternative to plug-in steam mops, which have become enormously popular for cleaning hard floors in the past two years. Again, the new device has the advantage that it is more convenient. There are no power cables, no water tank to fill or delay while it heats up.    Innovation: The Dyson Hard also serves as an alternative to plug-in steam mops.  Sir James said: ‘Good technology should make everyday tasks quicker and easier.

The new Dyson DC56 'Upright'

The new machine has the advantage that it provides two functions, cleaning both by vacuuming and a wiper method that can remove stains and dried food.

A special design has meant that the device can be turned into a cordless steam mop to clean the kitchen floor, which is quick and convenient using a pack of already prepared wet wipes wrapped around the device and clamped in place. These are available in a wood floor version and may also be used with packs manufactured by other companies.

In addition, the device incorporates a vacuum, which as in other Dyson products can clean up fine pieces of dust and dirt for hard floors.

Despite the extra features, the DC56 weighs only 1.4kg which is less than similar devices. On a full battery, the device can last for up to 25 minutes. The new machine is expected to be sold for £250 and is the biggest innovation since Sir James Dyson first launched his bagless vacuum cleaners 20 years ago.

Yoko Ono's publicist Kip Kouri's attorney Richard Klass filed a civil complaint in Manhattan court on Thursday. Kouri said he entered the restaurant and was refused entry by a member of the security team. After Kouri and his sister argued about the incident with staff, the security guard hit Kouri on the head and threw him through a glass door. During the fracas, Kouri ended up with several cuts and needed stitches. Kouri and his sister filed a summons against the restaurant on October 1. A study of more than 500 people showed that watching a video describing the experience of losing a beloved pet causes greater sadness than if the pet was a less cherished member of the owner’s household. The study, published this week in The Journal of Psychosomatic Research (1) in the Nature Publishing Group, sheds new light on the close connection between our experience of sadness and the animals that we share our lives with. For some people, pets form intimate parts of families and social units in the same way that other family members do. As the pet matures, the bond between it and its owner becomes stronger in a similar way to the relationship between parent and child. So much so, that, for some people, the loss of their pets can be devastating. Yet this grief, and the sadness that accompanies loss, may not be given the same credence as the grief a person feels in losing other human beings in their lives. And as a result, many of us fail to realise that there might even be differences in the way the minds of pet owners and others process sadness. The pair were originally charged with attempted murder but the court accepted their guilty pleas to wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm.
Munyankore was jailed of 10 years, nine months and Mohumed for nine years, four months at Leamington Justice Centre.
Mohumed had entered a guilty plea to the lesser charge but Munyankore was handed a longer jail term at the hearing on Friday after admitting the offence on the fourth day of a trial.
Det Con Helen Keating, of West Midlands Police, said it was unclear what sparked the row between the two defendants and the 26-year-old victim they had known for seven years.
Doctors said he was "lucky to survive" his injuries to his chest and legs, with one wound puncturing one of his lungs, diaphragm and liver. They were inflicted by a half-moon shaped dagger.

[Coventry Telegraph, Coventry Evening Telegraph] The pair were handed their jail sentences at Leamington Justice Centre.
[Coventry Telegraph] The victim was airlifted to hospital after the afternoon attack on 11 September.

Lightning has erupted from the plume of an erupting Chilean volcano. It is similar to the lightning in a volcanic plume in Iceland earlier this year, but of a different mechanism. There are usually two distinct types of lightning around volcanoes -- that similar to lightning of thunderstorms, called conventional lightning, and the more uncommon form known as ball lightning. However, the unusual form found at the erupting Chilean Cordon Caulle volcano is of yet another type.
. The erupting Chilean volcano is spewing out gases composed of mainly sulphur dioxide (SO2). SO2 acts as a free radical which can combine with oxygen and moisture, in a similar way to how ice particles form in an ordinary (non-volcanic) cloud.
. The SO2 particles can combine with other particles, such as water and dust, making small droplets of liquid water. These droplets are similar in size to those found in the clouds of an ordinary thunderstorm.
. There are however no ice particles formed with the SO2 so the water droplets can combine directly with the charged particles within the cloud to

In a paper written by two MIT graduate students, the researchers said they tested their theory by having a computer program scan millions of online articles and posts. The authors concluded that news articles often are used by hackers as a vehicle to spread malware. The two computer scientists said their study highlights the need for web users to view online articles skeptically, even after they have been reviewed by editors. In this study of about 3.5 million news items gathered from July, 2004, through March, 2010, about 63,000 contained malicious links. Of those malicious links in the news stories, 70 percent were active for less than a week. About 5 percent were still active a year later, and about 1 percent were still active four years later.  ```   Source : http://www.upi.com/News_Track_Desk/2014/01/12/MIT-study-News-stories-spread-malware/1371394564206/   Related Links: http://www.upi.com/News_Track_Desk/20

In 1841, the British invaded the Chinese city-state of Hong Kong to create a colony with special trading rights. Under Chinese rule, the region had long served as the gateway to the world's then greatest market, now known as China. In 1997, China took back "reunification," but in accordance with the "one country, two systems" principle, the former colony and most of the land has been administered for over 50 years now like the semi-autonomous state of the "Special Administrative Region."

Mary Beard wrote about how she was struck by the phrase "no crib for a bed" as she perused the lyrics printed in her order of service.

Professor Beard said of the printed lyrics: 'It did make you reflect on what made a good carol, what was the right blend of sentimentality and jolliness. It also made you reflect on how weird some of the words were (what actually does "no crib for a bed" mean?),' she added.

The confusion is thought to arise from the fact that - at least in Britain - a crib and a manger are essentially the same thing; a trough from which an animal can eat fodder. But in the U.S., where the carol was first published in Philadelphia in 1885, a crib is defined as a small bed for infants and young children.

Professor Mary Beard, a Cambridge university professor, attended a carol service in a Cambridge church where she noticed that the familiar words of Away In a Manger were a bit off. The lines go, "the little Lord Jesus, no crying He makes", and "His mother Mary meek and mild in a manger laid lowly for her Child". `pork DNA has been found in halal chicken sausages served in some schools in London ...

The consumption of pork is forbidden under Islamic law. Westminster City Council have named the school involved as St Mary's Bryanston Square, a Church of England school in west London. In the meantime, the council said it had asked its contractor to no longer use its Halal meat supplier. The problem came to light after the authority decided to carry out its own proactive tests on food contamination in the wake of the horse meat scandal. The council said officers took seven samples in total from three schools in the week beginning February 25, adding that the tests 'were carried out on our own initiative and not carried out as the result of any specific concerns about school food standards'. ```

Pork DNA found in halal sausages served in schools. Other tests revealed that lean minced beef supplied to the council showed evidence of lamb and pork DNA. The council removed the food supplier immediately after the contamination was discovered, and temporarily ceased supplying meat until the issue was resolved.The consumption of pork is forbidden in Islam. Westminster City Council did not reveal which schools had served the sausages, the contractor supplying the meat, or the supplier of the pork-tainted meat. Griselda Blanco was a notorious Colombian drug lord who rose to power in the 1970s and 1980s.

During her prime, Blanco was responsible for organizing the trafficking of massive quantities of cocaine from Colombia into the United States, making an untold amount of money in return.

But the gangster's life ended tragically, as it did violently.

Earlier this month, Blanco was shot multiple times in Medellin, Colombia.

She died from her gunshot wounds days later, and rumors continue to abound about her death. According to local authorities, the hit was ordered by a gangster named Frankie, a fellow drug dealer that had issues with Blanco.

Although at first, these claims appeared to be credible, recent developments indicate that Frankie, whose real name is Jorge "Pacho" Herrera was arrested today.

Local authorities also announced at a brief news conference that the police were investigating Blanco’s connections to former Colombian President Ernesto Samper Pizano, and an official stated that the president may have been involved with the slaying.

`In 2017, the Living Streets Scotland charity proposed a pilot project to ban car travel around all schools, in a bid to improve air quality and road safety for children. The group wants the scheme to be rolled out nationwide. The 18-month pilot scheme was implemented in Edinburgh in September 2015 and finished in March 2017. The scheme involves banning vehicle traffic from 8:30-9:30am and 2:30-3:30pm at nine schools.

    The results showed that more children were walking at pick-up and drop-off times when the scheme was running. On the other hand, less children were walking just before the scheme was launched and after it ended.

    A report to the city council's transport and environment committee recommended making the pilot permanent.

    However, Living Streets Scotland wants it extended nationwide.

    Stuart Hay, Living Streets Scotland director, said: "We are calling on all local authorities to look at this scheme.

    "All local authorities have similar problems.

Nuclear option' would be changing of Senate rules to enable judicial and executive nominees to be confirmed with just 51 votes instead of 60.``` * ```There's no nuclear option. Nuclear would take 50 votes to invoke cloture. Nuclear would take 60 votes to pass a measure.``` * ```There is a way to get something done in the senate. Senate moving toward 'going nuclear' Actually confirming the nominee or passing the legislation takes only 50 votes, but because of the procedural rules, it pretty much takes 60 to invoke cloture and get anything done these days. By requiring only 51 votes, the entire character of the chamber would change. Instead of being forced to get buy-in from the minority party (Republicans right now), the majority party (Democrats right now) would be able to confirm anybody for whom they could get a simple majority. Actually 'going nuclear' is going to need 60 votes. That's because the Republicans themselves are proposing it -- and the filibuster is so ingrained into Senate tradition that there is no way they would allow Republicans to eliminate a power that was used against them, without giving them an equivalent say in the matter. The minority party has to agree (via a vote) in order for the new rules to take effect. It won't be happening any time soon. If the Republicans win back the majority in the 2014 midterms, they'll have 270 days to do whatever they want anyway -- and can use that time to force the Democrats

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada has announced that if Republicans refuse to yield any ground on judicial nominees, he will take the "nuclear option" and re-structure Senate voting procedures to require only 51 votes to confirm presidential nominees to any position that has already been confirmed at least once before. This would have been a simple change several years ago, but as filibusters have increased since 2009 such that only a minority of senators can prevent a vote, the Senate cannot confirm even nominees that were supported by all senators before Republicans started blocking such confirmations, because Senate rules require 60 votes to end a filibuster. Reid blamed Republicans for the procedural standoff, saying they have "gone over the edge" by blocking all of President Barack Obama's nominees.

In a speech on the Senate floor on Thursday, Reid called the blocking of nominees by Republicans "outrageous" and "completely out of order," adding: "With each day that passes, our democracy is increasingly threatened by this inaction. ... Of several hundred phone calls to one big provider, just 7.7% were inquiries about cashing in a whole pension. Hargreaves Lansdown said the first day of the reforms - Bank Holiday Monday - was relatively quiet. Most calls were about long-term pension plans, such as buying an annuity, or setting up drawdown plans. The government's guidance service has also got off to a a quiet start. So far, just 380 people have booked face-to-face help sessions with Citizens Advice in England and Wales, although the booking service has been open for more than two weeks. Nearly 1,400 people have booked guidance over the phone with the Pensions Advisory Service, while just under 200 have already had appointments. Experts - including the Association of British Insurers (ABI)- have been advising people not to rush into new pension arrangements.
