In the Holy Trinity Church crypt, Northamptonshire, UK, scientists have found a lot more human bodies than they expected. There are two 13th Century crypts in the UK, and Holy Trinity Church's is one. The bones found had been radio carbon dated as being from around 600-1200. However, testing revealed skulls were older and some bones in the crypt were as new as the 1800s or early 1900s. It's not clear why the bodies were in such great numbers and why nobody has done this kind of research before, especially after the discovery of 2,500 bones was reported and the skulls found in the crypt were described as being of soldiers and plague victims. The scientists suggest that the Holy Trinity crypt was originally intended to be a place where the local people could be prayed for if they died. The building was supposed to protect their souls. They suggest that the people buried in the crypt are the ones who died then. But they are still unsure why the crypt contains bodies from the 1800s and 1900s. They need to investigate further to find out when the bodies in

```````````````````````````````````````` The Holy Trinity crypt in Rothwell holds hundreds of skulls. Scientists are trying to work out who they were and why they were buried there.

A skull is examined at the Holy Trinity crypt in Rothwell. Photograph: Dan Taylor/PA. Scientists are trying to work out who they were and why they were buried there. Radio carbon dating found some skulls were older than first thought.  But scientists from the University of Sheffield, who "assumed the ossuary was a medieval thing", were also surprised to find bones from the last century.

"It seems people continued to put skulls and bones down here, not only into the post-medieval period but even as late as around 1900," Dr Lizzie Craig-Atkins said.

The Holy Trinity crypt in Rothwell holds hundreds of skulls. Scientists are trying to work out who they were and why they were buried there. In 2012, scientists from the University of Sheffield were given permission to examine the skulls and bones, some of which are hundreds of years old.

Ronnie Lee Gardner, who is set to die next week before Utah's firing squad, said something Thursday he didn't plan to: He supports capital punishment. But, Gardner told the five-member Utah Board of Pardons and Parole, he thinks the death penalty needs to be "as fair as you can get it." Testifying at his commutation hearing, Gardner said he accepts responsibility for killing two men and seriously wounding a third. ```Article: I usually patiently explain that if I knew what was in the chancellor's red box, I probably wouldn't have to work for a living. It's always helpful to remember this when MPs start cheering реannounced tax cuts or fuel duty freezes. For саvers, the annual ISA limit rises from £15,240 to £20,000. Corporation tax will be cut from 20% to 19%. Insurance premium tax will rise from 10% to 12% in June. Chinese budget airline will be jointly owned through a venture with the Everbright Group, a financial investment firm.

AirAsia Group has announced plans to launch a new airline in China after signing a partnership deal with the Everbright Group.
The agreement, which was signed on 19 March, will see the new airline fly throughout the country from its home base in the central city of Zhengzhou.
Based in the central eastern city of Zhengzhou, the airline has set a launch date of 17 March 2020. Once officially active, its first two routes will be to Beijing and Xi'an.
AirAsia's chief executive Tony Fernandes said: "China has been good to us, and we want to give back in a big way, and this is [but] the start of an enduring partnership that will benefit both China and Malaysia".
The 100-plane carrier will be the 11th of the group. This will help the group to operate more than 500 aircraft across 250 routes, flying more than 90 million passengers annually in 20 countries, and with hubs across Malaysia, Thailand, Japan, Philippines and India.
AirAsia already has four subsidiaries across Asia, namely,

In a news release on Friday, AirAsia, the budget airline co-founder Tony Fernandes and the investment group Everbright Ltd. announced the new joint venture, AirAsia China (Hangzhou) Co., which will be based in the country's eastern city of Hangzhou.
Once for the privileged few, flying domestically within China has boomed. AirAsia says the move will help the airline tap into pent-up demand in China and help meet the needs of its travelers who want to fly domestically. “This Chinese venture represents the final piece of the AirAsia puzzle,” said chief executive Tony Fernandes, adding it “closes the loop” in the region. ```

A pair of French thieves posing as police officers stole £173,000 in cash from a Saudi diplomat minutes after he had landed in Paris after they pulled him over on a busy motorway. The robbers took a suitcase from the boot of the official's car which contained 162,000 Euros, $30,000 and £10,000. Driving a car equipped with flashing blue lights with 'police' written on it, the thieves pulled the diplomat over on the A1 just outside of the French capital. The armed men demanded an inspection of the car boot and said they were 'confiscating' the suitcase before telling the official, who had just landed at the private Le Bourget airport on Monday, he was 'free to go'. A French police spokesman said: 'It is unclear why he was carrying so much cash. We do not know if the robbers were working on a tip off or simply got lucky.' He confirmed that officers in the Seine-Saint-Denis department were investigating the theft. The robbery is the latest in a string of thefts on wealthy visitors to Paris.

# Wales' unsung heroes 'moved' by awards

Article: Dr David Nott from Trelech, Carmarthenshire, took the International award and Cairn Newton-Evans, of Ammanford, won the Citizenship award.
The annual ceremony took place in Cardiff on Thursday evening, with winners in nine categories.
It recognises the achievements of people in Wales from all walks of life.
While eight categories were nominated by the public, First Minister Carwyn Jones personally chose Sir Karl Jenkins and Dr Mererid Hopwood for his special award.
They composed the music and words for Cantata Memoria, a piece of choral work to commemorate the 50th Anniversary of the Aberfan disaster.
All of the winners were chosen from nominees that included Nizar Dahan from Swansea.
The 29-year-old from Sketty had been working in property development as a marketing consultant when the harrowing images of a three-year-old Syrian boy found drowned on a beach in Turkey drove him to act.
It led to him establishing the Swansea Humanitarian Aid Response Project -

Wales' Young Person of the Year award winner has been a vocal campaigner for children's rights throughout his charity work.
BBC Newsbeat reporter Tom Rogers reports.
Nizar Dahan has been a vocal campaigner for children's rights throughout his charity work.
He has helped hundreds of refugees living in appalling conditions across the world with his charity SHARP - which stands for Swansea Humanitarian Aid Response.
A huge part of 29-year-old Nizar's job is to talk, both to adults and children about their experiences.
His passion is clear, and he's driven to do even more.
Nizar's SHARP charity raises money and sends people they know to war torn Syria, as well as Greece and Jordan to bring help and medical aid to those who are suffering.
When a 3-year-old boy was pictured on a beach, it was that picture that changed Nizar's life.
The picture showed the motionless body of Alan Kurdi, a toddler who drowned with his brother and mother as they tried to cross the Mediterranean.
Nizar saw it while he was working as a marketing consultant.
He went out

The death of a cricketer has lead to Twitter pictures of bats by members of the cricket community. Many followers marked this event by posting photographs of their bats on Twitter, followed by #putoutyourbats or #putyourbatout. Paul Taylor started the trend. He put out his own cricket bat outside the front door and placed his hat on it. Taylor stated that he could not believe the response it got and it became Twitter users worldwide who posted photos of their bats, followed by #putoutyourbats or #putyourbatout. The pictures were sent by Twitter users across the world with #putoutyourbats or #putyourbatout. Paul Taylor was reluctant to talk to people until he read the story. The pictures were sent by Twitter users across the world, to express the grief of the loss of Phillip Hughes, a cricket player.```

An Indian government website was closed for maintenance on Friday, a day after hackers, reportedly based in Pakistan, brought down its cyber portal.
The hackers, who claimed responsibility through their official Twitter page, had earlier defaced the website of the Indian Council for Cultural Relations (ICCR).
A message was posted by the hackers on the ICCR website, which has now been restored, but is locked for outsiders with an information saying "the server is very busy".
The National Informatics Centre (NIC), which operates the government of India's cyber portal, had said that its site was down for maintenance.
In a separate attack on Wednesday, hackers had broken into the government website with the country's cyber emergency response team's domain name - cert-in.org.in - on their site.
The attacks come days after the Chinese government blocked access to several Indian websites including that of the country's National Security Advisor.
The hacker group had posted messages on the National Cyber Security Portal - http://www.cert-in.org.in/ - claiming to be responsible for shutting down the government's website.

SUMMARY:

Article: It's something you don't see every day: A Republican governor speaking at an inner city church, trying to end the stigma associated with drug addiction.

"We have to acknowledge the disease and treat their illness," New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie told a crowd gathered here for a forum he organized.

"We would never stigmatize someone who has cancer. Yet, we feel free to stigmatize someone who may have tried - made one bad decision - and because of their makeup, they become an addict."

For Christie, working with former drug addicts could be helpful if he decides to run for president in 2016. The image could humanize a governor who is better known for his tough talking, finger wagging style. ```

A hiker has been rescued after spending three days stranded with her two dogs in the wilderness, surviving on just wild mushrooms and bark. Restaurant manager Paula Reuter, 21, from Seattle was picked up in the Snoqualmie Pass, Washington, by helicopter on Thursday after putting up smoke signals when she got lost. With temperatures plummeting to 4C (40f) and only wearing a skirt, she moved around for two days in a desperate bid to get back onto the hiking trail, but kept heading deeper into the forest. Text: A hiker has been rescued after spending three days stranded with her two dogs in the wilderness, surviving on just wild mushrooms and bark. Restaurant manager Paula Reuter, 21, from Seattle was picked up in the Snoqualmie Pass, Washington, by helicopter on Thursday after putting up smoke signals when she got lost. With temperatures plummeting to 4C (40f) and only wearing a skirt, she moved around for two days in a desperate bid to get back onto the hiking trail, but kept heading deeper into the forest. Scroll down for video . Safe: Paula Reuter, 21, is wrapped in a blanket after spending three days in the wilderness near the Snoqualime Pass near Seattle, Washington . Rescued: The restaurant manager was airlifted to safety after using her lighter to start a smoke signal . As time went on, ate frogs, a rabbit and beef jerky Miss Reuter had stashed in her, while she was left to eat pine bark and porcini. The Dorchester carried about 1000 people to Greenland for a military mission.  The ship was torpedoed.  There weren't enough lifeboats for everyone.  Only 230 of the 900+ on board survived.  The survivors gave up their life jackets to the other men.  Four US sailors, known as the Four Chaplains,  gave up their life jackets to men who didn't have one, so they would drown in the extremely cold water.  The Four Chaplains were Reverend George Fox of the Methodist Church, Rabbi Alexander Goode of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, Reverend Clark Poling of the Reformed Church in the U.S.A., and Reverend John Washington of the Roman Catholic Church.  They survived 3 hours floating in the water and then died.  They died on February 3 1943, not very close to the 2013 Super Bowl.```

There were more than 900 people on  the Dorchester ship. Many were little more than boys.  After two days, the iceberg had made a hole in the ship and  the water was rising rapidly. The command said the boat had  enough lifeboats to carry only one-third of the 900 passengers  and for the rest, the boat had life jackets.

  A Lutheran minister, Rev. George L. Fox, from  Maine, told them how they could find eternal peace. Then all the  Lutheran pastors went to the boat and helped each one of the  men.

  The pastors' courage gave their men so much  faith that they gave themselves to God. The pastors said  goodbye to their own sons and to their men.

  About 300 men survived. They were not the strongest, nor  the youngest, but the 300 men that had faith. These  men got to live with their families, or were allowed to  serve other missions.  A small book, “God Was Our Submarine'' was later written about  their amazing survival.

Rolf Harris will serve just under three years in a British prison for a series of sex offences against four women and girls before he is eligible for parole. The Australian entertainer will first serve about half of his total sentence before he can earn some remission from further behaviour in jail.

He was convicted at the Old Bailey in London in July on 12 counts of indecent assault between 1968 and 1986.

The 84-year-old was cleared of five other offences against four other alleged victims, who gave evidence during his month-long trial.

His victims included a seven-year-old autograph hunter, two teenage girls and a friend of his daughter, whom he abused for more than 16 years.

Harris had not been in court to hear the sentencing due to poor health.

Judge Justin Riley sentenced Harris to at least five years, and no more than five years, and nine months in prison for the offences.

The judge told Harris: "I am satisfied that this was a persistent pattern of abuse of young girls over a considerable period of time."

Many of us have a need to be liked by others. Some people go to extreme lengths to get approval from others. They are called overly compliant people. Some people want to please their friends and don’t mind doing what they can to help the other. But many people like to appear to be likeable even to the point of being insincere. Unfortunately many of us have learned to think of people liking us as being a measure of our worth. This view is false and can lead people to say and do things that they believe will make others like them. It also leads people to be anxious if they believe they are not performing well at the task. Sometimes these people fear rejection in a romantic relationship or in a family or group context. But there is also research by psychologist and sociologists showing that people who are highly likable feel socially insecure in groups. Article:
Perinatal health covers the time during which a woman is pregnant and up to two years after she gives birth.
Post-natal mental illness, or as it is commonly known, post-natal depression, affects around one in ten mothers here.
Dr Janine Lynch said the current situation is serious.
Post-natal mental illness can be chronic, even life-threatening, when a woman is not offered specialist treatment in either a hospital or by specially trained staff.
Dr Lynch says the current situation is serious: "Women's lives are being put at risk due to the lack of specialist care. And none can be treated alongside their baby when they are feeling at their most vulnerable. Mother and baby have to be separated."
At the moment Northern Ireland does not have an inpatient specialist mother and baby unit. In fact there is only one specialist psychiatrist for the entire region.
Therefore when a woman is admitted to hospital for post-natal depression treatment they are separated from their baby.
According to the Royal College of Psychiatrists, on average, 75 Northern Ireland mothers per year require admission to hospital.

Auchterarder: Pupils and public learn life-saving skill

Six hundred people from Perthshire were shown at an event in Auchterarder how to restart a heart as part of the Save a Life for Scotland campaign, which is seeking to train half a million people to perform CPR.

Dozens of mannequins were placed on the floor in one area of an assembly room and pupils from P7 to S6 at the Community School of Auchterarder were taught how to carry out the procedure.

The campaign aims to train half a million people to be able to carry out the procedure.

The day was organised by the British Heart Foundation.

Participants were taught how to carry out chest compressions on the mannequins by instructors - and a "drowning" mannequin was used to show how to use a defibrillator.

The pupils are absolutely loving it.

We thought it would raise the awareness much more if we made it a whole school event.

A French consular agent has been arrested on rape charges in Bangalore. He faces charges of rape in India, police have said.
Investigators in the southern Indian city began an enquiry on Friday after his Indian wife alleged he sexually abused their three-year-old daughter.

Officials at the French consulate said they were cooperating with authorities and it remained in touch with the family of the child.
The official is being questioned by police and is expected to be charged later.
Police in Bangalore have not revealed who the accused is or the name of the agency he represents, but French media have identified the official as a consular agent.
Consular agents are lower-ranking staff and do not receive diplomatic status, which provides a degree of protection from legal prosecution in a foreign country.
The envoy denies the rape allegations, which were reported to the French Embassy in New Delhi

`
The accused, a French consular agent, was arrested on Tuesday morning and faces charges of rape, senior police officer Sunil Kumar told the BBC.
The envoy would be produced in court later in the day, Mr Kumar said.
The official was questioned on Friday after his Indian wife alleged he sexually abused their three-year-old. The envoy has made no comment as yet.
"The arrest was made after we got clearance from the [Indian] ministry of external affairs and home ministry," Mr Kumar said.
He said the envoy did not have diplomatic immunity and would be tried in India.
The wife of the envoy has written to the French ambassador in India and the Indian government, calling for her husband to be prevented from leaving the country until all legal proceedings are complete.
She has also asked the French Embassy for financial support for herself and her three children, who are French citizens.
On Monday, demonstrations were held outside the consulate demanding the arrest of the official. Police briefly detained the protesters.
As the protests grew louder, the French Consulate-General in Bangalore issued a press release saying it would cooperate with the

The Catholic Church sought a judicial review after the screen was installed on Hill Street close to Newry Cathedral in December 2015.The church said it was not consulted about the screen - and that was a breach of planning rules. The Newry Reporter said that the court overturned planning approval on Monday. The screen had caused controversy when it was installed because of its close proximity to the cathedral. Canon Francis Brown, from the cathedral, told the BBC that the church and parishioners were "delighted" with the court's decision. "We had a number of issues with the screen," he said. "For one, it was in front of the most historic building in the city. It was also distracting from Masses and services held in the cathedral. "Another issue was that people driving down Hill Street were seeing flashes on the screen and it was distracting drivers." He said the matter would now be "re-determined by the council" but that the church would oppose any move to keep the screen.
